A perfect game for those who are looking to think just enough to be engaged. Perfect companion to boring lectures, podcasts - but still enough fun to stand on its own. Addicting and relaxing fun.

Dorfromantik effortlessly weaves together the tranquility of pastoral landscapes with the satisfying challenge of strategic puzzle-solving. Its charming visuals and soothing soundtrack create an immersive environment that beckons players to lose themselves in its serene world. With each tile placement, players embark on a journey of creativity and discovery, building picturesque villages that unfold like stories waiting to be told. Whether you're a casual gamer seeking relaxation or a seasoned strategist craving a delightful challenge, Dorfromantik delivers a uniquely captivating experience that's as refreshing as a stroll through the countryside.
Simply fantastic!
a fun challenge with charming graphics

The perfect game. I game to relax and this is my favourite. Calm and cozy puzzle solving with the just the right amount of predictability to keep you chilled while still engaged. It offers a variety of game modes including a "sandbox-like" creative mode which doesn't have any rules, or you can opt for custom mode where you set the rules and the game generates a challenge for you. I love the art, the way you can see a world develop right in front of your eyes, the attention to user experience and perception, the colours. It runs on my machine with no fuss. A beautiful example of what game development can do for stress relief honestly.

Quick Description:
-Dorfromantik is a really peaceful, well designed management puzzler.  This game is great.  It has a really cool visual style, has a really tranquil soundtrack, and is super easy to learn but offers some strategic decision making w/ every choice you make.  While I do think there is a good amount of depth, my favorite part of this game is how easy it is to play while doing other things.  It's a great pallet cleanser after playing a really demanding game.  Having said that, some ppl are able to string together crazy high scores that I could only dream of, so clearly this is a skill based game w/ a decent learning curve.  

Consensus:
-Solid Game (Tier 3 and makes up 35% of my reviews).  I recently compared this game to Can't Live Without Electricity, and I think there is a good amount of overlap between the two.  I do prefer CLWE, but I think this game is really fun too.  I also think this is an easier game to learn, feels less chaotic, and has such a cool visual aesthetic.  I think the price point is spot on, but is really easy to recommend if there is any form of discount available.

Secondly, river and train tiles are fucking irritating; there's no proper explanation for how to place them, or why your ability to place them is restricted. Dorfromantik is intended to be a cozy puzzling experience where you place down pieces so that the corners are of the same type, eg. houses on houses, trees on trees, etc. and you are given missions to complete that want a minimum number of tile types, a specific number of tile types, and for you to "close" a patch of tiles. Doing these actions gives you more tiles and if you run out then it's game over.

On a casual level, this game is great. I love seeing the world come slowly to life, along with the brain teasing conundrums you run into when you get low on tiles. There's also a creative mode so you can just build whatever you want. However, I personally think high level Dorfromantik is fundamentally flawed in a way that could only be fixed from redesigning the whole game from the ground up. You see, completing quests is not the only way for you to get tiles. If you create a "perfect" tile (aka all 6 of its sides are matching), you get an extra tile. This might not sound like much, but then you realize that in later parts of the game this means you get 1 tile for placing a tile plus the rewards from missions means you can effectively go infinite (and people have). The problem is that perfect tiles are so important that they make missions pretty much worthless- it is actively better to squander a mission and never close patches of tiles in favor of making more perfects. This also means that the pace of the game slows down exponentially as your board gets bigger, as you find yourself scanning for tens of minutes for just the right place to use your tile.

This wouldn't be a problem for most players since it's a "casual" game, but then paradoxically the game wants you to reach ridiculous scores to complete its meta-progression quests, which means inevitably you will stumble upon this truth if you want to get better. Some people may enjoy this style of gameplay, but I find that it clashes with the atmosphere of the game and building a little land of your own, as you're no longer thinking about how your tiles look placed down and more at the cold hard numbers.

All that being said, I'm sure for a lot of people this scratches that OCD itch, and more power to them. It's not like I'm immune to it either, I just would have liked it if the game incentivized you better when you become really skilled. I may not enjoy it much anymore, but I'm still giving it a positive review because I definitely got my money's worth of entertainment out of it before I began to have issues.

A casual, fun, "boundless" puzzle game.  

Starting from one placed tile you begin the game with a stack of 40 randomized hex tiles with each tile being a set of different environments.  By matching the edges to like sided edges you can create a grouping of that particular environment, influencing your placement score.  The game play mode offers a series of different tasks/quests to be unlocked through manipulation of the hex tiles, spinning them (or not in the case of one achievement) to get the best combinations to fulfill the objectives unlocking new tiles/achievement lines.  Through the finishing of these tasks you get additional tiles added to your queue and the game continues until you run out of tiles.

Additionally there is a free play mode where you can cycle through tiles at your leisure building your own idyllic landscape without being bound by the normal game play mechanics.

It is a dangerous game that can easily and stealthily steal hours of your day!

Remember those childhood days of curiosity, wonder and pride when you hammered colored wooden triangles, cylinders & cubes into holes, smashing it in like there was no tomorrow? (Erlend Loe: [i] Na√Øve. Super. [/i]) Try to recall the giggling giddiness of pure unadulterated joy when you found a puzzle piece that fit just perfectly, neatly, effortlessly into the big picture you were trying to complete. Reminisce for a moment about the more sophisticated sense of accomplishment when you managed to repair a device, a bike, a car, a watch, or anything else and how that ability changed how you look at yourself and at the world of 'fixing stuff'. (R.M. Pirsig: [i] Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance [/i]) Now imagine a game that creates a semblance of these cherished feelings; easy-to-learn basics, a sense of wonder, playful exploration, improvisation, endless combination, love for detail. Actually, no need to imagine. Just play [i] Dorfromantik [/i] ... now that i posted this review, i can get back to it.

[h1]A Charming and Creative City-Building Gem[/h1]

[b]Dorfromantik is a delightful and visually stunning city-building game that captivates players with its charm and engaging gameplay. While it might not be an entirely laid-back experience, it cleverly balances relaxation with strategic thinking, making it a thoroughly enjoyable journey.

One of the standout features is the variety of modes available. The ability to manually customize tile generation in different modes adds a layer of personalization, allowing players to tailor the game rules to their preferences. Monthly activities bring a competitive edge, offering a chance to compete with others and showcase your creativity.

The creative mode is a highlight, providing a blank canvas where you can generate any tile and construct your dream world. It's a testament to the game's versatility and the freedom it grants players to shape their unique landscapes.

Dorfromantik goes beyond the typical city-building experience by integrating Steam achievements seamlessly into the game. Completing in-game challenges not only unlocks in-game accomplishments but also mirrors as achievements on Steam. These tasks serve as dynamic objectives, prompting players to adapt their strategies‚Äîwhether it's creating expansive waterways, intricate railway networks, or dense forests.

I highly recommend Dorfromantik to anyone seeking a refreshing and engaging city-building game. Kudos to the developers for crafting such an enjoyable experience that seamlessly blends creativity with strategy. Don't miss out on this gem![/b]

So these 4 German students, inspired by German board game design, made Dorfromantik. Then some other Germans took this video game, and turned it into a board game, which eventually won the coveted Spiel des Jahres prize.

10/10, precision German-engineered meditative gaming

I like Dorfromantik for the most part. It's really meditative when you get in the flow, and the music is calming.

For some reason I thought there would be levels, but it's just one main level where you try to beat your high score (plus a creative mode, too, which is nice).

There will be quests and requirements that get you thinking about tile placement and how to achieve better scores. You'll get better as you practice.

In the menu you will also see challenges you can work towards as you play the game. You can get new tiles/skins by completing them. They are linked in with the Steam achievements. There are base challenges such as "place 250 tiles in total" and "gain a highscore of 10,000". But the other challenges you need to unlock.

This is where I feel a bit iffy. To unlock a new challenge, a pre-placed tile will appear on the board, slightly further out. You then have to build up to that point to "uncover" that tile. It will have its own quest which you must fulfil to add the challenge to your menu.

These extra challenges will be things like "score two perfect placements at once" or "build a forest with at least 250 trees". In my opinion, these should already be unlocked from the get-go. It feels weird to have to obtain the challenge card first - especially if you've already done some of these requirements! I don't know, I just like getting achievements without stipulations...

That aside, it's a good puzzle game. It's pretty to look at and my favourite part is the different biome tiles which give you different colours across the board.

I'll keep playing for sure. I recommend this game on sale.

I feel like it could be more and yet I keep coming back every now and again for an hour of chill. It's very challenging if you want to build the "perfect" level, I don't even know if it's possible (I'm sure it is, but I haven't looked into it) but eventually it always breaks me and I end up building something that's good enough, which in itself is quite cathartic. Not sure how much more I'll get out of it but do not regret the purchase. 

If you are looking for a sweaty city builder this certainly is not it (luckily that's not what I expected anyway), but it can provide quite a steep challenge as more of a puzzle game and I found provided a really relaxing experience.

My main frustration with this game is all the missed opportunities to create game dynamics that would enhance play. I mean it's ok to potter around and place tiles until it gets a bit meh, but I can't help but feel it lacks the ability to really give players any real game mechanics that allow greater creativity and beauty.
If this game had babies with chip chain then I can imagine they might be better.

This is a great puzzle like single player game that creates a unique and scenic landscape every time you play.  Matching the edges of each tile with the same type terrain gets more points, but there are also random objectives that if completed give you more tiles.  Since the session ends when you run out of tiles, you must balance high score moves against moves that complete objectives.
This game reminds me of two board games:  It looks like Settlers of Catan with its octagonal tiles with landscape pattern, yet it  plays like the board game Carcassonne were you try to line up square landscape tiles to complete objectives to get a high score.  If I were cross those two games and make them a single player game, I imagine I would have Dorfromantik.
I found the game very calming, with a a relaxing soundtrack.  Animals, boats, and trains travel accross the scenery as you play and the trees sway in the wind.  I love this game!

At a certain point every run it seems like you end up having to prioritize either a higher score or an aesthetically pleasing board, and trying to balance the two always seems to trip me up, but the randomness of the tiles means you'll never end up with the exact same setup twice. 

In short - if you want to de-stress and are looking for a relaxing game where you can just chill but don't want to turn your brain off completely, I recommend Dorfromantik. If you're the type of person who likes aesthetically pleasing games that rely on chance, and love replaying rounds to beat your previous high score, then I also recommend this game.

This fun and addictive game is about placing landscape tiles. The hexagonal shapes have various possible landscapes for each side. Your task is to match them to like-sides. There are plains, housing, fields, woods, water, and train landscapes. If you can match all 6 sides on a piece, you score 60 points for a perfectly placed piece. This all makes each and every play-through different.

Complete tasks to gain more tiles, such as laying 63 trees touching each other, or 18 adjacent fields, BUT that number needs to be exact; not too many and not too few.

Sound easy? Give it a try!

I've been enjoying this, it can be somewhat frustrating at times which I haven't seen anyone else point out. It's worth noting that I don't care for actual physical like table top puzzles, but I do kind of like this. The problem is you want it to be relaxing and mindless but can often find yourself just searching and searching and NOTHING working. At this review I've got about 20 hours in and the top score I've managed was 28k, 

I feel like i'm still missing a fundamental aspect of reaching a flow state where I know what to do to get a more continuous run, and it usually diverges into damage control. This means you have to place tiles you don't want too place, just to get perfects and keep yourself afloat as when you run out of tiles the game is over. (Perfects are when you place a tile that closes another tiles last edge and that tile has all 6 sides perfectly lined up. This gives you 1 tile back so you don't lose any tiles) but that is a slippery slope down hill if you don't get them very regularly and is not sustainable to use damage control. For things to work you have to get to a place where almost every tile you place is also reaching a perfect place.

So all in all I do like this, I just wish it was a little easier on the brain. Definitely worth the money though for some hours of experimentation!

The board game has much better core game design. In the board game, nearly every tile feels meaningful, there is some structure to the randomness (e.g. you know which quests are left in the deck, and also which tiles to some extent). The regular quests require an exact number of tiles in a group, discouraging mega-groups (mostly), and encouraging precise planning.

The digital version feels tedious in comparison. Tons of random tiles and quests. Most quests are "x+', so you just build a big city, big river, big forest, ... .

The sense of progression is also much better in the boardgame version with a tech tree, compared to the achievements in this game.

Beautiful to look at and soothing to play. Dorfromantik is a puzzle game about well-placed tiles. It's simple, engaging, and doesn't make you feel bad for making mistakes. The rules are simple:

- Place tiles to create beautiful landscapes.
- Place a tile so that all 6 sides match to get a perfect placement bonus. 
- Complete missions (X number of Y tiles connected).

Everything else in the game is just a variation on this. Doing well is rewarded by more points and more tiles, meaning bigger landscapes. Doing poorly isn't punished at all.

This game is perfect for the Steam Deck. You can pick it up and put it down at any time.

I am highly confident in saying that you will not regret picking up this game.

I think the game has A LOT of flaws in terms of gameplay choices - it could have been much more fun!
But I don't feel like reviewing this game too much because I actually don't feel confident letting this game run on my system in the first place- it does not feel safe for my hardware - so instead of a review I'll just write up a WARNING! (?)

Now my mid to high level maxed out Lenovo P50 notebook might have aged a bit over the years, but I can still run some pretty good looking games with no problem whatsoever. Lately Alien:Isolation for instance - I was surprised how cool my PC stayed on medium settings. Dorfromantik however is a very different story. 
I cannot understand how a game like "Dorfromantik" makes me worried as to whether my pc survives another session - like the hardware gets alarmingly hot and the ventilation is running at max speed constantly, it's crazy!
I am by no means a computer expert so this is just an uninformed opinion but this game feels really really badly compiled and programmed - it feels like it wears your hardware down to a very unnecessary degree, something that in my opinion should not happen!
Has anyone else had this experience?!

Easy to play, and pretty to look at.

Edit Addition: normally with casual games I tend to fall off of them and stop playing but Dorfromantik has a very interesting pull. I think it might be because I genuinely don't feel pressured to beat my high score etc. I have more fun trying to fit pieces together that I couldn't even be bothered to track my tile count at times. There's more enjoyment in the moments where you finally get the perfect piece to fit on all six sides! The artwork is incredible, the soundtrack is simply delightful and I also appreciate all the updates the creators have done, I am a fan of the undo button as sometimes I make careless clicks trying to move around the map.

I really enjoy playing this game. It is a challenging puzzle game to create a world of water, trees, and towns and it changes every time you play with unlockable pieces you can use in subsequent playthroughs. There's also a high score feature that I appreciate as a marker of how well I do when placing the tiles for each play session and in comparison to other players.

I highly recommend this fun and easy-to-play game for anyone who is looking for a relaxing world building/creation game.

The notion that this game is a "relaxing" strategy game is a downright lie.  Essentially a tile-matching game, the nature of this game is that you have a limited number of tiles to play, yet if you can make a perfect match on every edge of a tile (which usually means on other tiles that you "complete" the edges for after playing more tiles), you get another tile.  There are also "quests" to make "runs" of a certain size, but before too long, those are for things like "a river 120 tiles long" or "1,600 trees in a forest", and you get 5 tiles for completing something it takes 120 tiles to make.  So basically, anything less than constant, relentless perfection is [b]FAILURE!![/b]  

Also, the achievements that are the only progress this game has require constant perfection.  As in, one of them I was given recently was "place 250 tiles in a row that are perfect placements" (another is that you aren't allowed to rotate tiles anymore), and somewhere around 230 perfect placements in a row, I apparently either placed a tile imperfectly [i]and didn't know it[/i] because the game's interface is [i]way[/i] too subtle about a faint red line (which can be occluded by quest markers or buildings) to actually see it every single time when playing sessions for hours.

So, again, play this game for the "relaxing" time of having felt like you were getting good at this - you're over a thousand tiles into a game, the map is huge, you have a score of nearly 100k, and 80 moves in the bank, and then you just keep getting railroad pieces you just can't match, and have to expand more out to the edges, and suddenly, without you [b]ever[/b] making a bad move, you're at less than 10 moves left and you're left with the inescapable feeling you just [i]ruined[/i] a run you spent the last week on in a single day and everything you did for the past week was an utter waste.  Due to the sheer randomness, even tiles that [i]should[/i] be common, like plains with two farms on opposite ends of the tile that I set up at hour 1 of my second game was a tile that [i]didn't come until 30 hours into the game, or several thousand tiles later[/i]!!  Due to the nature of how perfect tiles work, you've sunk 6 moves in the hole if you can't fill in a perfect match to a tile you've left as a hole, and you have breathing room of maybe 120 tiles, so you can afford to be waiting on as little as 20 tiles that are a "hole" when there are tens of thousands of permutations of tiles that might appear.  Even more insidiously, however, is that every single piece along the edge (where you keep your odds of leaving matches open by having less confirmed edges) is essentially a frozen drain of a tile until every edge is completed, making an expanding map an increasing debt you inevitably drown within. 
 Every single tile you have to skip and just hope you get a matching tile for it later as you advance forward is like a bleeding wound sucking at your nerves for [i]hours[/i] as you try to hold out until the match gets dealt to you by a merciless RNG that I [i]swear[/i] is [i]explicitly[/i] designed to hold out on pieces you need.  You know, "relaxing", like inescapably being cornered and drowned by debt.

But OK, it's horribly depressing and ruins your whole day that the game you looked forwards to playing after getting home was a total disaster through the game's own fault, but you can get back on the horse after taking a bit to recover from the crushing disappointment of your second game coming to a crashing end, right?  Well, haha, sucker, you still need to get nothing but perfect moves, and in the sixth tile of the game, you get handed a windmill with only farm edges and there hasn't been a [b]single[/b] farm edge yet.  RNG SAYS FUCK YOU, YOU LOSE!  START OVER, LOSER!  Oh, look, now you get an all-city tile before there's been any city edges to match it to!  YOU LOSE AGAIN, LOSER!  After playing my second game (for about 30 hours gametime,) it took about 15 tries to find a single game where it was even [i]possible[/i] to get established, and it quickly fell into a death spiral of no matching tiles after only another 4 hours trying to get my hopes up.  This game is just relentless kicks in the kidney by the RNG.  What [i]you[/i] can do about it doesn't matter, you just have to wait for the RNG to [i]let[/i] any strategy you might have start to matter.  Even if you have a perfect strategy based on looking up the game's probability chart to give yourself the best odds, it's still luck.  You're still watching the Sword of Damocles that is the tile counter swing down with every tile you don't get what you need, and [i]that isn't "relaxing"!![/i] 

Speaking of strategy, this game even trains you to play it wrong.  Early on in the game, plains are much more common (presumably to make it "easier"), but this just puts you into a mindset that the strategy is to leave edges that are plains open because early in the game, they're easier to match (ESPECIALLY tiles which have rails, where woods-edges are nearly non-existant), only for this to [i]very much not[/i] be the case later in the game when an invisible switch is flipped and it's time for nothing but tiles with two rail edges, two river edges, a woods edge, and a farm edge with no plains in sight.  All those edges you left hours ago with plains exposed when those were common are now massive liabilities because the game taught you on one set of rules [i]then changed the rules on you without telling![/i]  In short, the game is deliberately tricking you into failing.

Basically, there's a reason I never play games that are entirely determined by RNG.  Leaving your fate up to chance is always only going to end in bitterness and depression.

Yeah, sure, this game has a "creative mode" with no move limits or score where you can "just enjoy making the scene you want", but this game's output is to art what static from a radio on the wrong frequency is to music.  It's pure randomly-generated noise, best exemplified by the railroads, which tend to be a tangled knot of spaghetti that goes nowhere and has no trains on one giant track, but two trains on a single track that have to phase through each other to travel down the single linear path.  It's just endless blobs of the same random stuff mashed together for no reason because this game encourages playing to the mindless procedural generation method of generating content.  There is zero ability to enjoy placing random tiles down for no reason, it doesn't even qualify as a game.

Rails in particular are poison to the game, as rail tiles are [i]vastly[/i] rarer than most other tiles.  A recent event popup even has a challenge where the dev mentions that there are "no rails to ruin your maps" because in this game, rails are apparently a force of pure evil and chaos that just exist to ruin all of civilization.  When I had holes in my map that I just couldn't fill, they were almost always because I had to wait for a rail of a particular shape to fit the spaghetti mess of rail tiles I'd had excreted onto me by the game.

There is no outside world, only hexagon tiles.
There are no loved ones in your world, only hexagon tiles.

At its core, it is a zen/methodically paced puzzle game involves you matching similar sides/types to other pieces. The game rewards you for building maps with as many perfect matches as possible while also fulfilling challenges such as X piece wanting to be apart of a 200+ house section, or a 400+ tree forest. I personally enjoy playing the game in the evenings or quiet weekend afternoons as a way to relax while having something to do (a lot of ADHD and ASD people struggle to actually relax or meditate, and for me this is really relaxing as it gives me dopamine for achievements, doesn't leave me alone with my thoughts, and provides flow-state). The music is pretty ambient, but there is no big sound cues other than those for achievements and perfect matches, so you can put on your own music of choice and not miss anything. The achievements are pretty in-depth and skill focused, so while the skill floor to play the game is low, it has a higher skill ceiling, which I like. On that note, there are creative modes, quick modes, harder modes, as well as a monthly mode with leader-board. Technically all the modes have leader-boards, but I find the monthly to be the most enjoyable and rewarding competitively as you are limited in space vs the hard mode which is just harder challenges. TLDR if you are looking for a cozy relaxing game, and enjoy the task of matching or sorting things for fun, doing puzzles, or other sorts of spacial strategy games, I would highly recommend this game.

Dorfromantik is a slow-paced puzzle game that invites players to unwind and immerse themselves in the serene beauty of rural landscapes. The game's title, a blend of "dorf" (village) and "romantik" (romantic), perfectly encapsulates the essence of this charming experience.
The modular nature of the game adds a layer of creativity. Each playthrough results in a different village, fostering replayability and ensuring that no two sessions are alike.

This is an incredibly relaxing game, but can also be deceptively challenging. If you just want to build a lovely countryside, you can keep on playing even after your tiles run out (though your score won't increase. 

The art is absolutely lovely, with the different looks available from different "biomes" keeping things fresh. The music, art, and simple gameplay all come together to make this an enjoyable game indeed. If you're looking for a relaxing change to add to your gaming library, put this game at the top of your list. I can't wait to see what Toukana adds next!

Excellent little puzzle game (you can spend an infinite amount of time playing it). Do not get fooled, this is a puzzle game, not a city builder. It seems very neat and relaxing, but if you want to succeed, you really have to give it your best effort and focus very hard. 

Pros:

+ Calming atmosphere
+ Beautiful style of art
+ Lovely music and sound effects
+ Challenging and motivating puzzle mechanic
+ Highly addictive

Cons:

- The tutorial is very basic and does not cover all of the elements of the game. Took me a while to figure everything out
- You get skins as reward for completing tasks (also achievements), which is nice. Unfortunately, you can only have three counters toward an achievement / skin active at the same time. This means, any progress you make towards achieving a skin which is not active is wasted. Therefore you have to grind for it, which I did not like.
- You have to match the edges of cards in order to score a lot of points. For some of the cards (windmill, mill, also water train station and lakes) it was not clear to me which kind of edge they would fit next to [UPDATE: the devs improved the mechanics - it is now more obvious which edges fit each other]

Score: 9.5/10

So, I got it because I heard good things and I like tile-laying games like Carcassonne, and it seemed like a nice tile puzzle game.

What I wasn't expecting was a deep strategy game. The core element of the game is the fact that if you get a perfect tile (6 matching sides), you get extra tiles to place. So while you're trying to complete objectives, you're also looking at perfect placements so you can keep upping your score.

Add to that the fact playing unlocks new tiles with new graphics that also affects the art style of the map, which is also lush.

So, yes, this is one of those deceptively challenging puzzle games that hits the right notes.

I'm nominating this for the Labor of Love Steam Award nomination, because you can feel that labor of love in this game.

Possible spoilers(?) or gameplay information: [spoiler] For those wanting to play for score, there is a perfection mechanic that promotes getting perfect-sided tiles to boost score while also meeting requirements on certain tiles. Each requirement you get will give you more randomly generated tiles to play around with. So, it's kind of RNG but most of the time you can make it work out with what you have already played. [/spoiler]

I would highly recommend this for casual gamers who would like to do something relaxing before bed or find a time-waster game that appeals to one's perfectionist self. Will say it's very satisfying [spoiler] seeing the "Perfect" pop up when you fully place down 6 tiles around the center tile [/spoiler], which really makes you want to keep doing it throughout the board. You can also unlock additional textures for tiles while playing the game, so have fun with that.

Anyway, I hope this helps. [TL;DR] This is a fun, relaxing game to play for whenever you want to build a city without much of the taxes or paperwork that comes with mayor stuff :p

Dorfromantik is a delightful gem of a game that has truly captured my heart. If you're seeking a relaxing and visually stunning experience, look no further because this game is an absolute masterpiece.

First and foremost, the artwork and design in Dorfromantik are simply breathtaking. The hand-drawn landscapes are so charming and picturesque that you'll often find yourself just gazing at the scenery. The attention to detail and the vibrant, calming colors create a tranquil atmosphere that's perfect for unwinding.

The gameplay is easy to grasp, yet it offers a surprising depth of strategy. The concept of placing hexagonal tiles to build a pastoral landscape is both intuitive and creative. You'll quickly find yourself engrossed in the challenge of creating the most beautiful and harmonious world possible. The game strikes a perfect balance between being relaxing and engaging, making it suitable for both casual players and those who enjoy more in-depth, thought-provoking experiences.

The relaxing soundtrack complements the gameplay beautifully. It enhances the tranquil ambiance and is just a joy to listen to while you immerse yourself in the world of Dorfromantik. It's a game that encourages you to slow down, take your time, and appreciate the simple pleasures of life.

One of the most appealing aspects of Dorfromantik is its endless mode. There's no rush or time pressure, and you can play at your own pace, creating your dream landscape without limitations. This design choice allows for a highly personalized and meditative experience, making it the perfect game to unwind with after a long day.

Dorfromantik's replayability is impressive as well. Each new game offers a fresh opportunity to experiment with different tile placements, develop new strategies, and improve your high score. It's a game that you can return to time and time again without it ever feeling repetitive.

In a world filled with fast-paced, high-stress games, Dorfromantik is a breath of fresh air. It's a peaceful, engaging, and visually stunning experience that will soothe your soul and provide hours of enjoyment. If you're looking for a game that helps you relax and appreciate the simple beauty of creating your own idyllic world, Dorfromantik is a must-play. It's a true work of art in the gaming world, and I can't recommend it enough!

I don't usually love puzzle games, but this one is so satisfying, relaxing and fun that I have been playing it constantly. I like it so much more than I thought I would. It is inexplicably fun to create beautiful landscapes one tiny step at a time. By the end, when I look back, I feel proud and accomplished as well as extremely satisfied.

I had Dorfromantik on my Wishlist for some time, always waiting for a sale greater than 20%. The overwhelmingly positive reviews intrigued me, but I was not moved to purchase. One day a streamer on Twitch was playing it, but I didn't recognize it at first. "Wow this game looks great! This is right up my alley! What's the name?" "Dorfromantik". 

From that moment I've been hooked. I downloaded it that day, and have already sunk over 8 hours into it over the weekend. Even my partner loves it, and she never games. There is something so rewarding about placing the tiles - especially when they match up perfectly - getting points, and watching your beautiful map grow bigger and better, that hits all the right spots. Hidden behind the very simple mechanics and beautiful design is an incredible depth and loads of strategy. Sure you can have an amazing time tinkering around and creating a cute little countryside, but you can also spend minutes agonizing over each tile placement and thinking ahead to reach those high scores.

Between this depth of play, the ease to enter and exit a game, and the gorgeous graphics and sounds, you'll be hooked just like I was. Fans of the board game Carcassone will feel at home, and to a lesser extent Settlers of Catan or Ticket to Ride. Even if you don't game, and ignore the quests and points, just making a really cool map with all the beautiful and varied tiles is bound to bring enjoyment.

Dorfromantik will undoubtedly be at the top of my favourite games list for some time, which is crazy to think that I had slept on it so long. I encourage you to give it a go!

For the Devs: Possible future improvements - not that they're really needed - but perhaps a new tile or two that can be unlocked and are ultra rare could be a great addition to the ones already available! Also, perhaps a 'power up' system could be interesting, where you can bring in certain powers to a game (for example, the ability to 'hold' a piece until later, or randomize one, or to undo two tiles instead of just one, or the ability to ignore the first loss of the round). These could help players really play to their playstyle and add an extra element of control to games.

First thing: This is not the type of game I ever considered buying. I'd seen it plenty of times, even on sale as it is now, but just never thought it was that appealing. Finally, the "overwhelmingly positive" rating - overall - which is one of those nearly impossible levels to achieve - made me pull the trigger.

Yes, it's relaxing, but it's not a "turn your brain off" game. It requires planning, forethought and a wee bit of luck doesn't hurt. It may even have infinite replayability. I ended up playing it for 8 hours on my first day. Yikes!

TL;DR: Boring. Overpriced. Missed potential.

As I approached the end of the first level I just put tiles wherever, to finish quickly and get to the next level. [b]But there is no next level.[/b] It's the same one, over and over. There's some unlocks, but not enough to hold interest.

At this price point I expected a full game, but this feels like a basic tablet app, or the "casual mode" to a more fleshed-out game.

[h3]Potential[/h3]

Here's where this review gets long. I'm gonna talk about how much potential this game has, and share some ideas, because tbh that's what makes it so disappointing, how much more it could have been.

It could have:

- New levels with their own challenges, restrictions, reskinned tiles, and special tiles unique to that level or area. Eg, a city area with factory tiles instead of farm tiles and trams instead of trains; a beach biome with more water tiles and no farms; a fairy kingdom with oversized mushrooms and dragonfly flight routes instead of train tracks; a zoo world where you get bonus points for grouping birds/mammals/fish etc, or a theme park world where massive roller coasters replace train tracks... there's endless possibilities with this game's engine.

- More mechanics besides "put tree next to tree", eg. bonus points if you put a train station next to a village of >10 houses, or if you connect villages via railways. Atm you're incentivised to keep everything separate, [i]especially[/i] train tracks which heavily restrict their adjacent tiles.

- Having a choice between 2 tiles would be great. I actually enjoyed the game for a while when I was imagining how I would build the area, with its history and current culture -- but despite being simple, the system is too restrictive to give you any lasting sense of creative freedom. Having a choice of 2 tiles instead of 1 would give players a feeling of control and authorship, and let them steer the direction of their current world so each new one feels less repetitive, without disrupting the core score chasing mechanic too much. (Yes, there's a Creative Mode, but I need some restrictions and goals to keep me interested and motivated).

There's [i]just so much[/i] you could do with this game's concept, I could go on for ages with other ideas. I'm still gonna try another run, maybe try to unlock everything and see if my opinion changes, but as said, atm this feels like either an app store game or an early access build.

A nice puzzle game to play every now-and then. 

The store page explains it quite well. You try to place down randomly-generated hexagonal tiles so that their borders match neighbouring tiles. For example a tile might have trees on three sides, houses on one side, and farm fields on two, and you'd want to place it so that the edges with trees are placed against the side of another placed tile that also has trees, while the side with houses is against the side of another tile with houses, etc.

Railways and rivers are a bit different as they have to be connected so that one railway track/river goes into another without ending at the edge of a tile.

You only have a limited number of tiles, but you can get more with "quests". A quest can be generated by a tile when you place it, or by special tiles that appear on the map, with the quest activating when you reach the tile. A quest is visible as a little speech bubble above a tile with a number indicating that you will be rewarded with more tiles if you connect that number of a specific feature to that tile. For example, it might say to connect 20 houses to that tile. Most tiles have multiple houses on them, so you won't need to connect 20 tiles with houses, but the connection needs to be continuous, with no other features like fields or water separating some houses from others, even on single tiles. It is the same with trees, water, etc.

You earn points every time the side of one tile is matched with a side of another with the same feature. You also earn an extra tile every time you get a perfect placement (a tile with all its sides matching the features on neighbouring tiles). Once you run out of tiles it's game over and you get your score.

Some things I would've liked to see are some sort of campaign and/or scenarios with unique challenges to keep things interesting, as the game is a little bare-bones, but the concept is good enough that it is still okay without. There are at least a few different modes to play around with: 
- classic (normal gameplay)
- quick play (awards fewer tiles so games don't last as long)
- hard mode (tiles have more difficult/varied feature combinations)
- creative mode (unlimited tiles and can place any you want)
- custom mode (allows you to specify some parameters like how often features appear on tiles, add a time limit, etc)
- monthly challenge (everyone is provided with an identical seed and a limited area to place tiles, you can look at leaderboards to see how your results compare to others)

This game is beautiful and the gameplay gets off to a strong start. Although my first game went well (I placed 780 tiles with a score of 42k) it also revealed to me that there are some serious flaws with this game's design. In particular, I would highlight four principal design failures:

1. As the size of the map expands, it becomes increasingly difficult to remember the ever-expanding wishlist of specific tile arrangements you're waiting for. It also takes longer and longer to find the correct place to put a tile as the number of possible placements continually increases. The result of this is that the pace of the game drags and the game increasingly feels like a tedious administrative chore. This problem could be fixed by having a button you can click in order to highlight any particularly good locations for a tile (e.g. 3+ matching sides). 

2. The number of possible tile combinations is so high that the chances of getting the right tile combination become very slim, particularly once you have more than 3 sides to match. This leads to a sense of frustration which is at odds with the intended relaxing game experience. This problem could be fixed by including a new type of tile - a wildcard tile - which automatically morphs into the perfect tile once placed. This could be a special quest reward, for example, or perhaps could be awarded each time you achieve a certain number of natural perfect placements.

3. The mechanics of the river and railway tiles are fiddly and frustrating. The difficult of managing these pieces, combined with the ridiculous water station tile, means that the only viable tactic is to create an area just for them on one edge of the map. This leads to an unnatural and aesthetically displeasing map. These tiles should be removed as base tiles and instead should be overlay tiles that you place on top of existing tiles (as in Civilization V). This would not only alleviate issues 1 and 2 above, but could allow for more variety of quests (e.g. a quest to connect two closed town areas with a railway, a quest to create a railway which bridges over two different rivers or spans a large area of water, a quest to create a river which travels through three pure forest tiles, etc.).

4. The gameplay is fundamentally just not interesting enough. More thought needs to be put into how to make a game which has mechanics beyond tile rotation. This game needs things special base tiles which actually do something (as opposed to being purely cosmetic), overlay tiles that go on top of existing tiles to allow placement of rivers, railways and roads, a greater variety of quests, maybe even power-ups which could be won by closing an area (e.g. dynamite to destroy a previously placed tile, an axe to turn forest into plains, etc.), etc.

There is the foundation of a good game here, but it needs significantly more development to make it enjoyable to play.

While many copy cats have emerged since Dorfromantik, this romantic village puzzle game has paved the way as a classic. The various landscapes, differing biomes, and complex quests and challenges keep the game fresh. The colored tiles are ever-changing and random allowing enhanced strategy, though the game can be as relaxing and cozy or as challenging as you'd like (especially if you want the achievements related to not rotating the tiles). There's nothing like finding a perfect piece to the puzzle, but it can be just as satisfying to just relax, explore, and build a cute, cozy, colorful little world. Having to deal with some of the achievement based quests has helped me to better accept when things don't fit just right, but getting a perfect 7 tiles matching fuels my OCD and ADHD in a way where I feel relaxed and accomplished and can do anything (like play another game of Dorfromantik to try and beat my high score). 6.5/10

Dorfromantik has been on my mind since it launched in Early Access, and let me tell you, it‚Äôs hands down my favourite time-killer in my massive library of games.

It‚Äôs super easy to jump into, doesn‚Äôt bombard you with a million things to do, relaxed to the max ‚Äì but here‚Äôs the kicker: It‚Äôs surprisingly deep. I mean, it depends on what you‚Äôre expecting, but bear with me.

Dorfromantik doesn‚Äôt have fancy gimmicks or make use of confusing elements. Nope, it keeps it simple and sweet, hooking you with gameplay that‚Äôs consistently enjoyable. Just place your tiles on the board and try to score as many points as you can ‚Äì and here‚Äôs the deep part, I suppose: Points vary based on placement, like, what you placed it next to, how many of the same tiles are connected, how many of the tiles next to this one has matching corners. And on top of that, you got little mini-quests that need fulfilling in order to bring in more tiles for you to place, and more tiles = higher score. As a bonus, you unlock new types of tiles by finishing achievements.

But even with all that, it‚Äôs the kind of game that lets you genuinely relax ‚Äì from the relaxed gameplay loop, to the pretty visuals, and the soothing musical score. Honestly. While the game can be considerably more involved if you want to chase score, at no point does it force you to do this. It even helps you along with where to place tiles.  

Oh, yeah, the friggin‚Äô music! Let me tell you, it‚Äôs like the musical equivalent of, well, whatever truly satisfying thing you prefer. For me, a hot cup of instant coffee with a splash of milk and an episode of The Wire. What? I‚Äôm a simple man.

In the world of casual games, Dorfromantik is the one that shines the brightest. It‚Äôs got an undeniable charm. It‚Äôs a bit like Civilization, not in terms of gameplay, mind you, but in that ‚Äòjust one more turn‚Äô kind of way. You‚Äôll find yourself stuck in it for way longer than you intended. If you‚Äôre in the mood for a casual/puzzle game that‚Äôs the absolute chilliest something can be, do yourself a favour and dive into Dorfromantik.

Trust me, you won‚Äôt regret it.

A fantastic terrain building tile game. You build little towns, woods, fields, rivers, lakes etc. by rotating and placing down terrain / building tiles to slowly create your own mosaic-style world map. 

The challenge is to match the tile sides up as best as you can to get more points. You get points for completing these quests and for matching as many sides as possible up to all of them being a perfect placement. Also, to try to avoid running out of tiles by completing the little "quests". Which are to match up over a certain number of tiles e.g. connect 10 field tiles. Or, more difficultly, matching up an exact number of tiles you can't exceed.  Which tests your overall planning power! 

The aesthetic is a bit reminiscent of the Catan board game, very cutesy and simple bright colour palette. The ambient music is very peaceful and the sound effects when you click a tile down are very satisfying. 

All in all, very addicting and meditative game to play when you're not sure what to do with a few hours. 9/10

Look, you gotta try this game, alright? I mean, what are we doing here? I thought I'd just give it a quick spin, ya know, a little test run before going back to the grind. Next thing I know, it's four hours later! I'm telling you, it's like meditating with challenges, man! If you wanna zone out but still feel like a genius, this is it. 

So don't walk, RUN to get this game! But I'm warning you, ten hours from now, you'll be wondering where the day went. Unbelievable!

"Dorfromantik" is an absolutely enchanting experience that mixes tile-placement strategy with peaceful world-building. You're handed a stack of hexagonal tiles featuring various landscape elements like forests, fields, and rivers, and it's up to you to create your own sprawling, harmonious landscape. The art is gorgeously whimsical, and the calming background music makes it feel like a meditative retreat.

What really makes the game stand out is its accessibility matched with underlying complexity. On one hand, it‚Äôs a laid-back game that allows you to create picturesque tableaus at your own pace. On the other, there are missions, challenges, and combos that bring a strategic depth to the gameplay. Each tile placement matters, affecting your score and future options, so you're constantly engaged.

If you're a fan of puzzle games or just need a tranquil escape from real-world chaos, "Dorfromantik" is a must-play. It‚Äôs the perfect blend of casual relaxation and engaging strategy, making it easy to lose hours in its captivating, ever-expanding landscapes. üèûÔ∏èüß©

This is a funny game. Better said, this is a game that has funny tags. If you look up above at the most relevant tags you see "City Builder", "Turn Based Strategy" and "Puzzle". Of those three I'd say only puzzle is 100% relevant. Especially in terms of what you'd really expect from these tags traditionally. When you think "City Builder" you normally think of games like Tropico, Cities: Skylines or Simcity. Yes, you can build a very large town by connecting lots of house tiles that could constitute a city, but it's not what you think it is. Same goes for Turn-Based Strategy yeah, you lay down one tile at a time. So one could call that a turn. But it's not like Civilisation or Total War where there are clearly defined turns as such.

That being said, was this a delightful discovery? Absolutely! It's addictive, soothing and simply fun. This game is to me, a classic example of "don't judge a book by it's cover" and "you should really give a wide net of games a go!". While I do enjoy board games and this game very much feels like one, it certainly was not what I was expecting. And it turned out to be an incredibly pleasant surprise!

The graphics and feel of the game are all very lovely. My only criticism is the music. I think it's ok, but honestly, I think they could have been a bit more adventurous with it and gone with something a bit more melodic rather than something that feels like it would play in the background at a spa. Like I get what they were going for, they wanted something calming and inoffensive to try to appeal to as many people as possible, but I don't generally agree with this sort of thinking. Things designed by committee are rarely good. I think they should have let the composer be a bit more adventurous.

All in all. Very solid game that definitely deserves the overwhelmingly positive reviews it currently enjoys! Recommended!
so relaxing, and complex at the same time

A lot of the reviews for this game paint it as a chill, calm, no-stress puzzle game. And it could be played that way, if you didn't care about the score, unlocking additional challenges, or completing quests. If, however, you're the kind of person who does care about your score, unlocking additional challenges, or completing quests, it's a stress-filled RNG nightmare. You start with six quest types (or challenges) unlocked, and as you progress through the game you can reach preset tiles on the map and complete their quests to unlock a new quest type (or challenge).

For instance, you may encounter a preset tile with a bit of forest and a quest to connect 500+ trees to it, and if you succeed at the quest you can unlock one of the remaining challenges. It doesn't seem to matter what kind of quest tile you encounter when it comes to unlocking the next challenge, and no consideration of which quest tiles have been placed at map generation is made when the game rolls your starting tileset. This is where the problem comes in. You can run into a til that wants 40 or 50 more field tiles attached to it, but the rest of the game you get primarily water or forest tiles, or city tiles, or even meadows, and you can just never complete that quest. This can go on for game, after game, after game, with no end in sight.

Pure RNG like this just ruins games, and it's such an easy fix, that games like this wind up infuriating me, rather than providing enjoyment or relaxation. So if you care about the score, the leader boards, or you're a completionist, I'd advise steering clear of this one.

Dorfromantik achieves what it sets out to do; it is a thoroughly engaging, minimalist, game perfect for when you need a little mental decompression, but still want to build something in the process. It feels a bit like making a sand mandala or working in a mini zen garden, only gamified just enough to give you some direction if you are not feeling purely artistic. Laying the tiles with the lite incentive of matching like hexagonal faces and completing the occasional "mission" to have X trees in a contiguous forest, etc, is never so intense that it causes stress.

Whats best for the FOMOphobes and 4x completion out there that struggle to  actually stop after "one more turn" You walk away anytime and there is nothing to remember when you come back, you don't even need to actively save the game. Better yet, theirs no draw back to starting over either.

I'm really glad I gave Dorfromantik a try. As someone with pretty high-functioning ADHD, it's always been hard for me to "shut off" my brain - not to stop thinking, but to focus on the here and now (sort of like mindfulness) - but with this game, I find I'm able to without any trouble. Dorfromantik has just enough challenge that I don't zone out, but I focus on it and stop thinking about anything else, and it's really relaxing. Not only is it a ton of fun (as well as fulfilling, knocking out task after task) but it's a great way for me to wind down in the evenings before I go to bed. The art is charming, as is the music, and I would definitely recommend it to anybody who wants a nice puzzle game to help them relax.

[b]‚ÄúThere will be no dwarves nor romance‚Äù[/b]
[i]-M. Night Shyamalan[/i]
[hr][/hr]

[b]Dorfromantik[/b], a relaxing little game that instead will require every bit of your attention.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You have hexagonal tiles, used to create a countryside landscape, each side has a certain something on it, be it a house, some trees, a wheat field etc.

You get points for matching one of these sides with the ones from another tile, but what makes it so attention needy is the fact that you both have limited tiles and getting a tile that fully matches the surrounding ones nets you another tile.

The implicit objective of the game (and the one that unlocks achievements and other tile types) is going on for as long as possible, turning it form something calming to an exercise in patience, programming where each piece of the puzzle will fit.
[hr][/hr]

I had a pet spider (a bold jumper) named Sally who crossed the rainbow bridge yesterday. She liked this game, so I'm giving it a thumbs up. She lived on my desk in her little enclosure for almost a year and would turn around to watch me play this among other games. Her brain was only the size of a pea, and she probably didn't care about me at all. She only knew I gave her food and didn't smoosh her. But, she was really sweet and curious and fuck. I loved that spider, and I cried like a baby yesterday morning when I found her in her death curl. So, here's to you, Sally Spood. May you Rest in Spider Peace.

I don't write many reviews at all, but something about this game just makes me feel emotional. There is not a lot to it, place a tile, get points, more points for matching edges. There's just something more here, something special, maybe its watching your landscape grow. Maybe it's the music. This game makes me feel hope, like no matter how imperfect something is, or how you could have done better, it still turns out beautiful.

This is entirely my own issue, and I can understand why so many people love this game. But if like me you suffer from compulsive or completionist tendencies, this game may not be for you.

I really thought I would like this game, and I did enjoy it at first. After about an hour, though, I realized it was not relaxing me as expected but was stressing me out. There is a constant push and pull between new quests asking you to expand biomes and existing quests asking you to close biomes off. I never quite got the satisfaction of completion, because the goalposts kept getting farther away, and as the map got bigger and bigger it became harder to juggle the competing objectives. It was really hard for me to stop playing, but not in a fun way, and eventually I just needed to quit and walk away.

Casual puzzle game with hidden depths. Place tiles down on an a playing area to slowly construct a map, with periodic challenges set by the game to build chains of contiguous tile sets. The hexagonal pieces score points for corresponding with matching tiles (the egde of one tile with trees if placed adjoining another tile with trees scores points) with the objective being to construct something that is randomly generated but aesthetically pleasing. Your enjoyment will go as far as how much you enjoy pushing yourself for high scores - or enjoying the free play mode to build a world of pure imagination.

I really want to like this game, but I found it stressful to try to optimize tile placement and make a nice looking town.  They'll throw in random train tracks at times that don't make sense, and they're incredibly hectic, like a four way intersection, so you end up cobbling random things together in places you don't want to, and your town doesn't look anything like the pictures.  Ultimately, the game is very one dimensional -- they could have integrated systems to allow you more flexibility in tile placement while still retaining the core themes of the puzzle.  E.g. some sort of tile inventory, more flexibility on tile placement, something where the puzzle edges aren't all fixed and can be adjusted, allow you to cycle through tiles, etc.  Edit:  They could also add a system where it is easier to see when a tile placement is optimal, because if you're trying to be careful and strategically place your tiles, it's extremely tedious to find optimal placements when your board is large -- again some happy medium between doing it for you and being able to help filter information so it's not so tedious.

[h1][b]Relaxing with Basic Simplification[/b][/h1]

This is one of the most relaxing games you can play without being mind-numbing like solitaire.  Everything is simple and not overstimulating. With multiple modes and a wide variety of different biomes.  Biome being one of the most complicated words used. It does not use a wide variety of colors to distract the player. At times, I'm totally engrossed that I'm sitting up in my chair and calculating every move. Other times, I've been able to sit back, play while watching TV or simply falling asleep.  I've even played this game while I'm sitting in the queue to go into a dungeon or raid while playing World of Warcraft (WOW). It's that simple to play or to get involved with. 

With a creative, easy, and hard mode, there is something for everyone. 

This game does not take a major computer to run. I have had this running at the same time several major other programs and WOW at the same time. This takes up so little CPU and requires there are really no GPU requirements, it will fit in on the most basic computer.

[hr][/hr]

Teachers & Parents Will Find This Educational

This game requires some thought be given to the placement of tiles and the ability to assess your decision and count what the results are going to be. There is basic hints along the way with an undo ability built in for fixing a misplaced tile.  This is common sense for adults who have been through basic middle school. On the other hand students as young as kindergarten and who can count will find this game fun with the long run of being beneficial to their growth. 

With all math you need the ability to understand a mathematical equation, understand the order of operations and then work on the answer. From basic math to advanced balancing of chemical formulas its a matter of understanding what to do first and where your move one part of the answer to the next. 

This game does the same thing. With smaller numbers but it can teach a student to do fast thinking because the flags in the game tell you yes, no, or what your placement could calculate, to if you place the tile there. The same thing we teach students. We have children/students use pencils because they can erase the answer when they are wrong. Calculate your numbers really quickly before you give you final answer.  With a

It also teaches you to slow down. It is not a speed game, it is a matter of evaluating your options.  With a basic theme and no multiple scenarios i.e. water and transit for humans, it allows a younger player to learn and evaluate. 

It has the a 'Jackpot Pavlovian System' built in to allow for the student to be excited about what they have done and wanting to play more. It also has a scoring system which between siblings or students would encourage challenges and an eagerness to do better.  Younger children will only see they are being allowed to play a game, not as a chore. 

The game is on Steam. All younger children want to be like their parents and older siblings. Steam is considered the adult place to get games. Younger children will see it as a treat or reward, while adults will know they are learning something from games. 

This game could easily be placed in the educational category to increase audience size.  I would highly recommend the producers of the game to offer this to school districts for educational purposes.  As a professional sales person and account manager this game could easily be packaged and sold to school districts - parents would buy it for their children based on a recommendation from a school district.  

[b]PTA SUPPORT[/b] I spent eleven years for all my children's school PTAs. I served as a board member, auction chair, Ways and Means Vice President and finally as President. If any of the teachers or math departments from my schools had asked me to supplement their curriculum with this game, I would have easily put this to a motion and gotten approval. 

Thank you for producing such a wonderful game.

The game is really simple and relaxing and you can easily get into a "groove" of placing tiles for hours.

So  addictive!  My first time playing Dorfromantik kept me on my computer until 4 am...my feet are the size of watermelons.  I'm back at it at 8 am because I want to beat my score and I'm a glutton for punishment.  Pretty sure I'm gonna need a coffee IV drip today.

The game is simple to learn yet challenging.  No play-through will be the same.  I was pleased to learn that at the end of your game (when you run out of tiles in your stack) you have the option to continue playing in creative mode.  That's a nice touch; I definitely wanted to continue playing on the giant board I ended up creating. One thing I noticed when continuing in creative mode is that all your tasks are gone; it's a straight up creative playing board.  Dorfromantik is one of the best casual games I've played in a long time!

It's hard to play in an unexpected way: controls are fine, but the way the tiles are so adamantly constrained to only fit with other tiles is really irritating to work with and thus does not deliver on the promise of a relaxing experience. You will dread getting river and railroad tiles from the random stack because god knows when you're gonna be able to do anything useful with them, and more likely, you're just setting yourself up for later failure wherever you do finally decide to lay them down.

See each tile is generated at random and is based on the edges. If you place a tile and manage to surround the tile matching each edge you get a "Perfect" tile. How to enjoy Dorfromantik

Don't expect getting high score always. If you do that you really hate RNG tiles although that's the core of the game. Should aim for an average score always.

Should use quest and perfect tile bonus, so there is no time to play the game mindlessly, always focus to play wisely. If you're looking for a relaxing game, this game is not and I would recommend Mini Motorways which is a well balanced relaxing and puzzle game that you can play mindlessly..

Most negative reviews were posted by people who always want to get a high score or don't care about the bonuses instead play the game mindlessly. Dorfromantik isn't the game for everybody and the average global achievement rate is pretty low regardless of the overwhelmingly positive game. If you didn't find how to enjoy the game by yourself in the first 2 hours consider taking the refund, other than that this game is a pretty fun puzzle game.

I say this as someone who has scored 54,000+ points on a run, which places me above the top ~3% of players approximately, judging from the global achievement stats.

At first glance you may mistake Dorfromantik as some sort of chill city builder, but it actually is a very not-chill rogue-like jigsaw puzzler. The twist over a normal jigsaw is that you are allowed to "misplace" the pieces, e.g. the terrain depicted on an edge of the hex piece doesn't have to match the neighboring pieces. However, only "perfect" placements (where all 6 edges have a matching neighbor) grant you an extra piece to play with, and stave off your inevitable death.  

And therein lies my central complaint of the game: Poor UI when it comes to perfect placements. As you play and build out the puzzle, the number of gaps in it will steadily increase as your surrounding terrain restricts appropriate placements. A single hex hole will only have 1 perfect matching piece after all, and there tens of thousands of terrain combinations (albeit some are more common than others). It's up to you to keep a mental list of all the combinations you need, vs what's currently in your hand. 

Fine. What's frustrating is that you'll eventually forced to place a non-perfect tile to achieve a mission or just survive for another piece placement, and these ruined tiles are nearly indistinguishable from the perfect ones. You may think you have the exact piece for a given opening, only to find out you don't get as many perfect placements as you originally thought (or any at all). In my final run I was so fed up with this trial-and-error, that I eventually just slammed down my pieces to end the game, even though I could have spent more time finding more optimal placements to continue playing and get a higher score.

If there was a clearer indicator in the UI for marking non-perfect tiles, that would greatly relieve the montony and stress of filling in the gaps, as the barrier for finding a sufficient neighboring piece is greatly reduced.

Other thoughts:
[list]
[*]Matching terrain can sometimes be difficult to tell due to irregularity in the representation (related to the problem above). But at the very least matching edges light up white when you're testing piece placement.
[*]The unlocks and general progression could be more enticing. They're all just reskins, that's it. The biomes are pretty cool as they change the palette of a region via a gradient, but the rest are features that are so small that you're not really going to notice them on a large map. And they tend to be samey anyway.
[*]A "session" or run takes quite a long time. My 18 hours recorded was only from two sessions after the tutorial. If you play cautiously and optimally you'll live longer, but also the gameplay becomes a slog as you have infinitely-increasing choices of where to place tiles.
[/list]

There was some fun to be had, but overall Dorfromantik is a stressful chore.

Peaceful, relaxing and highly enjoyable. Kind of like a solo version of Carcassonne (a great boardgame) but more sprawling - a single, well-played game of Dorfromantik can go on for hours. But the game is so easy-going that even when looking to maximise the points for every tile placement, it never gets stressful. 
Before playing the game I watched a couple of reviews that criticised it for a perceived lack of direct goals and for the "luck-of-the-draw" element of the tile drawing. I'm glad I picked it up despite those reviews - those criticisms haven't been an issue for me. There are goals throughout and it's left up to the player how they want to approach them and which goals they want to pursue. And the game is no more "lucky" than any boardgame that features tile-drawing. And as with any of those other tile placement games, there are many ways to mitigate the luck (and rack up higher and higher scores).
This is definitely a game I'll keep coming back to.

If you want a chill low stress puzzle game with a beautiful art style this is the game for you. The game is based around connecting similar tiles to grow your puzzle board. City ties with cities, woods, farms, rivers etc. As you play the game you unlock new types of tiles. 
You can rotate the game board along with zooming in and out and see upcoming tiles. Connecting enough tiles together awards you more tiles and points. When you are out of tiles the game ends though there is an option to continue in creative mode. 
You can also start in creative mode if you don‚Äôt want to worry about running out of tiles or you do not care about high score challenges. 
This is the perfect game for relaxing or if you have a bit of time to kill and want something nice and mellow that you can pick up and put down easily.

Relaxing? Yes, but also... strangely stressful. Under this whole aesthetic of idyllic central European countryside there's a surprisingly deep game of matching tile edges, managing groups, closing off regions, fulfilling quests. You can, of course, ignore all of that and play creative mode exclusively, but I'd feel like this would be a waste of game.

There are two reasons to pay attention to these systems. One - score. That one might not seem that important, but it's fun to try to beat your own high score! Besides, it often leads to achievements, which in turn unlock new tiles and biomes. And two - it replenishes your tile pool. See, your pile of tiles is always limited - and once you run out, it's [strike]game over[/strike] session complete. So if you want to keep expanding your little world, you have to keep paying attention to these things.

The mixture of those systems and the incredibly chill aesthetic - both in terms of look and the soundscape - create a very unique and potent brew that just washes your worries away. And I think this is the main reason why the game is so beloved by many.

For example: this one time, I had a mental breakdown so severe, my entire concept of reality collapsed and even thoughts of suicide didn't bring any solace. I got out of it with the help of therapy, philosophy and some research, but what kept the mortifying existential dread at bay was this game. The chill feeling was strong enough to make me forget I spent too long gazing into the abyss, and undoubtedly made my recovery quicker.

With all that said, I wish the game had more object types on the tiles. There are only 3 common ones (there's more, but they're much less common): houses, trees, and fields. I get it, that's rural Europe for you, but we also have mountains! Meadows! Swamps! Admittedly, the devs are from Berlin (I think), and the state of Brandenburg is almost completely flat - so maybe that's what they were going for.

I wasn't sure if I'd like Dorfromantik, but it entered my life when I needed it, and returned some kind of peace to my soul. I won't claim it would do the same to you, but I'd say it's nice to place a few tiles every now and then.

Nice, relaxing experience, but after a while it gets repetitive, boring and even tiny bit frustrating. While I've had quite a bit of fun playing the game, I couldn't stop thinking how this game could be better. I like its visual style, changing biomes, those little ships and trains cruising through the map. Dorfromantic has relaxing atmosphere and brings joy from looking at those unique lands you can build there. But also I was always a bit frustrated because I couldn't really find any special strategy that could help me survive longer in a game. At some point you just get not enough new tasks and start to slowly spend more tiles than you are awarded with. So often after each completed task you wait for new one to start and you waste tiles waiting for it to show up. So many times you have like 3 field tasks, 2 with water, and all the tiles with forrest/city/train tracks are just waste. New tiles are 100% randomized and you're never awarded with tiles that you need - which would be great idea - you can either get lucky (rarely, due to high number of possible combinations), wait for ages for 100% matching tile or simply use one that matches partially. It would be so cool to get a special tile as an award - one that can be placed in any place and will fit all surrounding tiles. Or if you could swap current tile with different one. No. Obviously carefully considering each move can prolong the game, but eventually you will run out of tiles anyway. And while this is intentioned - what I don't like is the fact that final result is mostly dependent on that random nature of the game. If you scored higher than usual - it's luck, not your newly invented strategy or smart decisions. So it quickly becomes boring, as I don't see any incentive to play again if it's just luck that can get me further than before. It's definately worth checking out, spending some time with it, but the novelty and discovery evaporate quite fast and you're left with a bit of disappointment.

Very simple, very lovely. Could be considered overpriced but a few spicy additions to scoring could absolutely change that.
The joy of this game comes from placing down a perfect piece in a perfect place to hear the pleasant ping of "quest complete", and paired with a great artstyle and relaxed mood, it makes one hell of a combo. In the very light and soft way, of course. 
The scoring incentives directly encourage you to create nice looking environments, there are plenty of gamemodes to suit your mood. I can't really complain about anything, but that's mainly because there isn't much here. 
Some more interesting scoring criteria could add a lot of flavor, but there just aren't any. 
So... yeah. This game is exactly what it looks like. It won't surprise you, it won't blow you away, you won't spiral into addiction... but that's honestly alright.

edit: you will spiral into addiction

Whenever the world has got me down or a little high strung, I take a deep breath and play a game or two of Dorfromantik. It has a way of bringing me back down to Earth. There's some strategy, there's some progression, but don't sweat it, man! You're here to chill and build a cozy continent!

This would not be that big of a problem if it was easier to get perfect matches/combo's in this game but it's practically designed to not do that, so to play you must accept that things won't be perfect and, for now I cannot do that, although perhaps this game might eventually help me with that problem.

I gave this one a thumb up, but it's not a resounding success either.
DorfRomantik is a special kind of 'Candy Crush', except, in place of geometrical shapes, you have landscape elements (fields, forests, trains, water, grassland, and houses). As advertised, the mood is peaceful, and the pace of the game allows for a relaxing experience, supported by a calm and soothing soundtrack.
However, the built-in randomness ensures every landscape you build will devolve into a monstrosity. What makes landscapes relaxing is their underlying 'humanity', so when your creation turns 'inhumane', relaxation *can* go out the window. Also, as long as the music sticks to saxophones parts reminiscent of a Christopher Cross song, no problem. But when you suddenly have machine-guns roaring in your head because the next piano track is oddly evocative of the intro to that horrendous 'Man of Steel' theme...
That said, I feel like DorfRomantik somehow met its goals. It [b]is[/b] peaceful, and it sucks you in like a Solitaire (seriously, watch the clock when you play), but in a richer, somewhat less repetitive environment. And there are now different options that really let you play it the way you want to, including a 'sandbox' builder. 
So, in the end, despite its drawbacks, DorfRomantik is a game that will fit nicely in your Library next to titles like "Wingspan" or "Eastshade".

PS: watch the second video up there; it's literally a 3.30min demo showing you the [b]whole[/b] game, including a good tutorial.
