I hate this game like you wouldn't believe. It acts all friendly like it's some sort of relaxing chill hex game but it's just a visage to slowly grind away your sanity in what ultimately amounts to a massive waste of the minutes you have left in your life.

Oh, Dorf Romantik, you sly, deceiving little devil, luring me in with your adorable hand-painted graphics and soothing soundtrack. How could I ever resist? But just as I let my guard down, you unleash the hidden beast within.

You claim to be a "relaxing building strategy and puzzle game," but what you really are is a tactical mastermind that feasts upon my feeble attempts at creating idyllic landscapes. Yes, I see through your ruse, Dorf Romantik. You're not fooling me any longer.

Sure, the game starts off easy enough, lulling me into a false sense of accomplishment as I place tiles, creating quaint little villages and serene forests. But then, out of nowhere, you hit me with these so-called "quests" ‚Äì the windmill that demands six grain fields or the deer that wants a 50-tree forest. Well, guess what, Dorf Romantik? I don't negotiate with terrorists.

And let's talk about those "unlockable tiles and biomes," shall we? Oh, how exciting it must be to discover new lands, filled with new challenges! Except, you know what I don't need? More challenges. I have enough of those in my life already. If I wanted to feel the crushing weight of my own inadequacy, I'd just check my bank account or try to assemble IKEA furniture.

Oh, and don't even get me started on the high score system. You mean to tell me that not only do I have to suffer through this relentless hexagonal hellscape, but I also have to compete against others for the highest score? What kind of sick, twisted game are you playing, Dorf Romantik?

But perhaps the most egregious sin of all is the undo button and rotating the last tile to not lose. Yeah instead of losing my mind over the placement of a stupid lake tile, I could just enter creative mode but again there's the score I have to worry about.

In conclusion, Dorf Romantik is a heartless, diabolical game that masquerades as a calm, peaceful retreat from the chaos of life. But don't be fooled, my friends. It's a hex-shaped nightmare that will slowly, mercilessly grind your sanity into dust. You have been warned.

In need of a really nice chill game? This game is for you.
It is not a game you would play end to end in a sitting. It is one you would play it over multiple sessions when you just want to relax. 
Gameplay
In the beginning, you start with a stack of random tiles. The idea is to match as many as you can together to expand your playing field. You will be challenged to keep the groups together to reap the rewards of more tiles for you stack to keep you playing further. The challenge then is do you close out a group, or risk it for further rewards. Also occasionally in game play, you will extend you tiles outwards and a greyed out special tile will appear approx 10 tiles from the current edge of your tiled map. If you build to these before your tile stack diminishes you will be given a new tile type.
Soothing

What a fantastic game! You can pick it up just to relax and build a little Dorf (village) without worrying about perfection, or, when you're feeling analytical, strive to perfectly place every tile. There are a few different gameplay styles (encouraged by leveled achievements), and to truly master the game, you'll need to learn them all - or you'll run out of tiles and the game ends.

Perfection will result in lots of snaking connected fields, like farmlands or forests, while you hunt for the perfect tile to connect them. Placing those perfect pieces will earn additional tiles.

Caring less about perfection will have you focusing on completing quests, closing fields to get flags, and exploring to find bonus tiles. All will give you additional tiles.

Or, just play creative mode, where you have an endless supply of tiles, can skip tiles you don't like, and can generate perfect tiles to place in any spot.

I am delighted to share my positive review of Dorfromantic, a delightful and captivating PC game that stands out for its unique blend of puzzle-solving, strategy, and tranquil aesthetics. Developed by Toukana Interactive, Dorfromantic offers an enchanting experience that will mesmerize players of all ages.

One of the first aspects that grabbed my attention in Dorfromantic is its charming and visually pleasing art style. The game presents a picturesque world filled with serene landscapes, quaint villages, lush forests, winding rivers, and rolling hills. The handcrafted tile-based graphics are beautifully designed, evoking a sense of tranquility and immersion. The attention to detail is exquisite, creating a mesmerizing atmosphere that invites players to lose themselves in the idyllic scenery.

The gameplay mechanics in Dorfromantic are refreshingly simple yet remarkably addictive. Players are tasked with strategically placing tiles featuring various landscape elements such as forests, meadows, rivers, and buildings to create a harmonious and interconnected environment. The goal is to maximize points by aligning and extending the landscapes in a way that forms cohesive patterns and completes specific objectives. The intuitive and easy-to-understand mechanics make the game accessible to both casual players and puzzle enthusiasts.

Dorfromantic offers a perfect balance between relaxation and strategic thinking. The game encourages thoughtful planning and foresight as players must carefully consider the placement of each tile to maximize their score and create an aesthetically pleasing landscape. This aspect adds a layer of depth to the gameplay, making it engrossing and satisfying without ever feeling overly challenging or stressful.

The progression system in Dorfromantic is seamless and rewarding. As players continue to expand their landscapes and fulfill objectives, they unlock additional tiles and features that add more variety and complexity to the game. The sense of achievement and discovery as new elements are introduced keeps players engaged and motivated to explore further and create even more stunning landscapes.

One of the standout features of Dorfromantic is its relaxing and immersive soundtrack. The soothing melodies and ambient sounds perfectly complement the tranquil visuals, creating a peaceful and meditative experience. The combination of the calming music, gentle gameplay, and captivating visuals makes Dorfromantic a perfect choice for players seeking a moment of respite from the hectic pace of everyday life.

The developers of Dorfromantic have shown remarkable dedication to their community. They have actively engaged with players, listened to feedback, and released updates that have expanded the game's content and enhanced the overall experience. This commitment to continuous improvement and player satisfaction is commendable and ensures that Dorfromantic remains a delightful and engaging game for its ever-growing fan base.

Cosy yet addictive tile-based builder where the goal is simply to build a peaceful, bucolic landscape with as high a score as possible. 

You start with a fixed number of hexagonal tiles. Each tile can have some combination of grass, field, trees, houses, water or train track. You proceed to fit them together one-by-one, creating a landscape in the process. The size of your stack of tiles dictates how big a landscape you can build. Initially, not that big it would seem. However, you are given 'quests' as you proceed (build a forest with this many tress, a town with this many houses, a river this long etc), and as you complete these quests, you will gain more score and new tiles will be added to your stack allowing you to extend your landscape further. And this is really it. Once the stack is empty, it is over and you are left with a wonderful landscape and a high-score to chase. 

Simple but with just the right amount of engagement to make it fun but not so much to ever make it stressful. The art style is wonderful, the animations are relaxing, the music is chill. Runs can last from 30 mins to a couple of hours depending on well you are doing (but you can suspend at anytime and resume later). Also works wonderfully on Steamdeck. Highly recommended.

Steam told me I might like this game based on other games I've played. Steam was correct. Easy to pickup, tough to master.

Tiles have 6 sides and a handful of things that can go on a tile (as far as I can tell they're randomly generated) so it's up to you to find the best spot for whichever tile you're served until you're out. Two kinds of quests pop up as you play, either prompting you to link a certain amount of stuff together (like, link 10 trees together as an example), or having you close off what you've already made with the proper tile type. Completing quests gets you more tiles, more tiles gets you more points, and that's the loop.

My high score after 14 hours was about 14,000 - which felt like a herculean task and an impossible feat (I told my wife about it at dinner knowing she wouldn't care but I was THAT excited) - however I've seen numbers much higher and I'm actually quite low on the leader board. I don't believe there will be a day that will pass by without me playing at least one round.

Dorfromantik is a very laid back game.  There isn't a story line or even an ultimate goal.  There are quests and points, but ultimately they don't matter.  The object of the game is to create a landscape however you want with the tiles that you're given.  Sure you can produce your own goals like try to play as long as possible by earning more tiles, or scoring the most points possible, or try to unlock all the tiles that the game has to offer, but at its core this game is a creative endeavor to do the best you can with what you have. 

I can see the appeal of the game if you want something just to pass the time with.  The game is pretty, and the music is soothing.  But ultimately, for me, the payoffs of the game just aren't enough for me to want to keep playing.  Honestly it does feel like a .99 game you might find on an app store under "relaxing sim/puzzler" but sim and puzzler is used rather loosely here.  There is no real simulation of people, no economy, no resource gathering beyond tiles.... It's a terrain generation game.  

 There are goals and quests....  Each tile is hexagonal, and each side has a "biome."  You can line up biomes together to make larger villages.  Some terrains have hard rules like railroads restrict the end of the tile to only railroads.  Some tiles come with quests where you might need to connect 100 forest together in a continuous chain/blob, others ask that you get precisely X houses no more or less.  Sometimes there is a tile in the distance that is highlighted that you're supposed to build and connect to.  You get extra points for placing a tile that perfectly matches the biome to its 6 neighbors. The tiles, as far as I can tell are randomly generated, so you have to work with what you have if you want to maximize your score.  Some events like getting a perfect match gives you more tiles, but you start off with 100 tiles.  When you run out of tiles, the game is over, and you start over, with anything you've unlocked from the previous playthroughs.  There really isn't any penalty for not matching biomes up well, nor failing to complete quest objectives.  

There are also a creative mode which lets you generate/change the tiles to whatever you want so you can paint the map to how you like, stripping all of the loose game mechanics entirely from the game.  So if it frustrates you that the game "ends" you can turn that off.  

I can see how this game can appeal to a certain kind of game player in a certain mood, but ultimately, this game is not for me.

Dorfromantik is a well-designed puzzle game with unlimited replayability.

If you need something to quickly pick up and waste some time, Dorfromantik is a good choice for that. There are various modes (Classic, Quick, or Hard) that count towards achievement goals, but there are also Creative mode and Custom mode, which are just for fun.

The gameplay is rather simple at first glance but has some more depth once you try to get higher scores. The more different types of tiles there are, the more difficult the game gets, but that's not all, tiles can also have mixed types, so they become dead ends of sequentially placed types.

The nicest thing about Dorfromantik is its art style and how they dynamically change depending on the biome they are in or what other tile is next to it. Sounds are alright and the gamepad layout takes some time to get used to.

So, I've been playing this off and on after work as a way to relax and get into something simple that helps me to relax; which, to be honest... is probably exactly what this was intended to be and I love it for that.

It's a puzzle game where you attempt to match up tiles with towns, fields, forests, rivers, and railroads in order to up your score. As you fulfill certain quests (like x amount of forest tiles strung together) you acquire more tiles. Line up a tile on all sides with the corresponding tiles? You get another tile. Eventually you WILL run out of tiles but the objective is to rack up your score while simultaneously keeping as many tiles as you can coming back to your stockpile therefore keeping you in the game longer and further increasing that overall score.

It's an easy-to-grasp (and jump into) premise but addictive and thoroughly enjoyable with endearing graphics, audio, and musical score. I highly recommend for those who like puzzle games at all and need something to relax to!

Dorfromantik is a peaceful building strategy and puzzle game where you create a beautiful and ever-growing village landscape by placing tiles. You can explore a variety of colorful biomes, discover and unlock new tiles and complete quests to fill your world with life! It's a relaxing game that allows you to immerse yourself in a quiet, peaceful world at any time and take a break from everyday life. It's perfect for those who enjoy games like Catan and other tile-based games.

In Dorfromantik, you start with a few tiles and have to build a landscape from hexagonal tiles. You can create pine forests, patchwork fields, meandering rivers, spidery train tracks, and higgledy-piggledy little red-brick towns.  You can choose from a variety of biomes and discover and unlock new tiles.  

The game has a relaxing soundtrack that helps you unwind while playing.  It's perfect for those who want to take a break from their busy lives and enjoy a peaceful game.

I liked the game initially, I really did. And I still do love the quaint visuals and how the world comes together as you build it. But soon I realised that the game didn't really have the depth to achieve any of the goals I wanted from it.

As a relaxing game it fails because your continent soon grows too big to manage effectively and then you'll find your game ending sooner than you'd like because you ran out of pieces. You have the ability to port your game over to sandbox mode, which is nice, but by default it automatically borks up the colours and alienates your world from you. And by removing all the quests and connection bonuses alongside the introduction of the tool that'll make pieces, it instantly gives you a sense of pointlessness. What I really wanted was to just have the regular game continue. Let me go into piece 'debt' and continue playing because I want to accomplish all those quests. Or just give me 10 extra pieces and a slap on the wrist and say I didn't get the gold medal. Whatever, at least I still have a reason to keep playing...

As an engaging puzzle game it also dropped off for me because I realised I was just doing a computer's job. It's not very difficult to constantly scan the exterior of your board and compare the next piece to all the available slots. I made myself a document containing data on all of the available placements on my board and what each side required. Then when I got a new piece I could just look at my spreadsheet and it'd tell me if this piece fills any of the holes I needed it to. If you could communicate the game data to an AI, it could play this game. Which means it's not really a game, nor a puzzle. It's just work.

I mean look, I have 20 hours on the game, the game's $20 aud when not on sale. It's not the worst purchase you'll make but idk. Just left a sour taste in my mouth.

Fantastic game for what it is: Casual, relaxing, a modicum of puzzle gameplay and the feeling of setting up an itty bitty diorama of a town.[hr][/hr]I usually put this game on when I have a migraine or need to sit through a work from home meeting that I don't have anything to contribute towards. It's absolutely perfect for that, and if it sounds enticing I highly recommend it.[hr][/hr]The gameplay consists of placing 6-sided tiles that randomly have different attributes on each side. You link up waterways, plains, houses, railways, forests, and blank areas together and get bonuses for connecting certain amounts of tiles or maximal amounts of tiles. There are certainly min-max strategies to getting high scores, but it's never interested me to take this game that seriously.[hr][/hr]The more connections you make successfully, the more tiles are added to the stack allowing you to build further. There are special tiles to unlock by hitting certain milestones or physically stretching your towns in one direction for a while, like a little scene of a deer in a clearing in a forest or a tugboat on a river.The vibes? Immaculate. Chill background music and adorable visuals give this game a really cozy charm. The game is exactly what it looks like, so you can easily tell if this game is for you or not.[hr][/hr]I love a game that has a clear vision for what it is and achieves on it. I wish more games were as well executed as this one is.

[h1]Hidden Complexity in a Simple Puzzle Game[/h1]

This seemingly simple puzzle game will surprise you with its intricate gameplay mechanics and vast array of randomized tiles. As you dive deeper into the game, you'll find yourself creating sprawling landscapes with interconnected systems of railroads, tiny villages, and giant forests. 

The "secret" tiles you unlock through in-game quests only add to the depth of the game. While the cute cardboard art style may deceive you, this game is a true menace of complexity that will keep your brain tickled for hours on end.

[b]The normal price may be a bit high, so it's worth waiting for a sale. But if you're a fan of brain teasers and enjoy a challenge, this game is definitely worth picking up.[/b]

Oof. I really wanted to love this game- the art is so pretty and cute, and the tile placement thing seemed like such a neat twist on city builders, which I *love*. Before We Leave had a similar hex-based aesthetic, which I thought worked really well.

However, the game is extremely rigid, lacking even the flexibility of solitaire: you can't reshuffle your tiles or use anything other than your top tile. And you can only place tiles directly adjacent to other tiles, making it basically impossible to plan routes for things like rivers and railroads.

Overall, while I liked the aesthetic, I realized after about an hour and a half it was tedious and frustrating more than fun and relaxing.

The music fits the vibe really well and the controls are easy enough to pick up, and I'd give it a pass for how the different land types do not blend well at all, but the gameplay just isn't enjoyable.

I love RTSs and city builders, I have since the early days of Sim City and Warcraft II. I always wanted that sort of gameplay, but without the upkeep/conflict.

This is a relaxing, soothing game.  It's not here to measure your epeen, it's not here to prove how much better you are than the computer/ai/opponent. This is a game to play when the day has been too much and you need to UNWIND.

Remember unwinding?  Remember playing games for fun instead of endless challenge? Remember games as an escape from the horrors of reality? Dorfromantik does.

The gameplay is very similar to a hexagonal Carcassonne, where the challenge is in the tile laying not the upkeep and maintenance, but without Carcassonne's ridiculous point counting system.

I think even full price is well worth the enjoyment you can get from this.

This is a relaxing game, there is strategy and freeform beauty. The more you play, the more diverse your biomes will become, and over time you will design your lands not only for points or border matches, but because they look good and feel right. There is some skill and strategy involved to get the unlocks and progress. There are also new modes that enable a shorter, more 'completed' feeling from play.

It's a very cute game - reminiscent to me of the Ravensburger classic Roads, Rivers and Rails.

The player places hexagon tiles, matching different elements to create consecutive zones of the same element - in doing this they create rivers, towns, fields and forests. As zones are completed and scored, new tile types emerge, the denizens of the tiny world begin to use the railways and canals that have already been built, and so on.

It's a simple puzzle game, perfect for winding down for an hour at the end of the day. There are competitive elements to it, for those who are interested, but I haven't cared to explore that side of the game.
If you like calming puzzle games that aren't too serious then you'll probably like Dorfromantik.

Its a charming little game. The more you play the more you realize its a bit more than just placing tiles, or getting a bunch of tiles to work together. Its more like a puzzle you get to level up and grow. 

- Is it worth the price? Sort of, it really depends if you're into relaxing tile puzzle games.

- Is it buggy? I haven't racked up the hours to definitively say that, but given how simple this game is, bugs don't really seem to be an issue.

- Will i play it repeatedly? If you think this is your game, yeah you'll be like the others that return to it on and off again. It's not a fast pace adrenal pumper, as in, you won't have a lot excitement, more so it's like trimming a bonsai tree, or painting, or taking a nice bath. Its really meant to quiet down your focus and help you turn simple ideas into bigger more expansive ones.

tldr; if you like little trainsets, snowglobes, terrariums or any other little quiet nice soothing kinds of things, get this game, its well made for its total experience given but not really comparable to bigger action orientated genres.

Dorfromantik is the ultimate procrastination tool masquerading as a game. 
It's a digital version of adult coloring books, a puzzle on steroids, a black hole of tile-matching goodness that sucks you in and never lets you go.
A virtual puzzle but instead of just fitting them together, you get the satisfaction of creating a unique new world.
It's like meditation but with less incense and more pixels.
If you're looking for a stress-reliever, a  zone out or just something to kill time, give Dorfromantik a try. 
The only downside is that you might find yourself neglecting your responsibilities to play this game.
Just don't blame me when you realize you've spent the entire day trying to get perfect tiles instead of doing work.

I feel like the name of this game should be "Make It Make Sense," because that's what I say to myself with every tile I need to play. And I'm addicted to making it make sense. It's way better than Solitaire for a casual relaxing game that still makes you solve problems and organize your deck.  Sometimes your deck is extremely frustrating though, and you'll end up with a cluster of train tracks that blocks your forests or neighborhoods. Other times it's extremely satisfying to make your tiles fit together perfectly and build a world that makes perfect sense. After a few months my high score is only 14,000 though... I would love to play a much higher scoring game. It seems like when I get down to the last 10 tiles that none of them are what I need to complete a quest or make a "perfect." I'm still developing my strategy with this game. And I'm completely addicted to it.
Fun relaxing game

A very chill and relaxing tile placement game where you build a bucolic pastoral landscape by placing hexagonal tiles to build the world. There are little goals to achieve to give you focus like placing so many of a certain tile in a connected path of matching edges. There is no fail state really, you can place tiles wherever you like with no real penalty, though the game encourages you to prioritise clever and thoughtful tile placement to maximise your score or complete short term goals. Its all complemented by a lovely relaxing soundtrack that matches the soothing gameplay.

With no fail state this is a good game to zen out on between more stressful games or relax with on a break or before bed. It is not terribly complex but sometimes, that is just what you want. This is the sort of cozy game I like to fire up while I listen to a podcast as well, something stress free to multitask with.

[h1]As challenging or as chill as you want it to be[/h1]

Easy to pick up. Difficult to master. Cute design, chill music and good vibes. A great game to open up after a tough day, turn my brain off a bit, and just connect the pretty tiles. Also pretty easy to play while watching streams or shows on the side, since there's no time restrictions. 

It's relaxing [b]to a point[/b] -- unless you get super neurotic about tile placements like I do, in which case: late game can get a bit stressful and annoying because the game [i]just won't give you the right tiles[/i] to finish all the quests you've laid out [b][i]AAAAAAAAAAAA[/i][/b]... but that's just part of the game and determined by how well you've planned out your landscape vs. remaining tiles.

(I know there's probably some kind of meta strategy, but I literally cannot be asked to be that serious about this game haha)

Not sure if it's worth full price, but it's definitely worth it on sale!

Anyone who has played the board game Carcassonne will immediately recognize Dorfromantik as being based on the same sort of domino-like idea, but Dorfromantik is still significantly different. The main thing is that it's a solitaire game. It's also a little more elaborate and challenging due to the hexagonal tile design, and the game rules are somewhat customizable.

I'm not really a big player of these types of games and mostly got it because my niece and nephew like this sort of game (it's good for younger kids) but even I still think it's pretty good for what it is. In addition to the standard , quick, and hard modes, there is also a custom mode and a monthly challenge mode. The custom modes have a seed which ensures the same sequence of tiles for anyone who uses the seed, thus multiple people can compete to see who can get the highest score with the same tile sequence and restrictions. There's also a "creative" mode that, while I wouldn't call it a "true" creative mode, lets you just freely place tiles and delete/discard them to see what sort of map you can draw.

The UI is also simple and well designed, so any kid old enough to use a mouse will probably be able to figure it out pretty much immediately.

A really gentle game that slowly develops a world that you just want to live in. I love all the subtle details, the changes of day and night, as well as seasons. I don't like train tracks. They are ugly and get in everywhere. I wish I could turn them off. The final 20 cards of your stack gets a little intense. Suddenly you start really planning out your placements to get as many bonus cards as possible. 10 cards left? What can I do, I'm running out? 5 cards left? I can't possibly finish that town, but if I get one more water tile I might get 5 more cards to keep going. It is surprising how this gentle town builder becomes a bit more intense at the end.

This has been a wonderful chill out game. I didn't expect to be interested for this long but I find myself coming back to it when the wind is out of me for other things. 

It can be as challenging or relaxed as you want to make it depending on if you want to chase challenges/trophies or if you just want to create a visually appealing landscape in sandbox. After a while you get to know the tiles and can make more informed placement decisions. 

The BGM matches it also with relaxing ambient nature sounds. It also plays well muted while watching TV or listening to something else. 

I wish there were more style varieties but it is a minor gripe. I also have issues with cloud sync not working properly when going back-and-forth between my PC and Steam Deck. I have not found a solution for this which is a little annoying because it does play very well on Deck. 

I picked this up on a sale and would gladly recommend at full price.

Dorf Romantik gets a tepid thumbs-up from someone who's played quite a bit of the game; not because the game is bad, but because the developers refuse to implement simple optional controls and visuals for the visually and physically impaired. There are simple quality of life options users asked for back when the game released that still haven't been implemented to this day. Other visual cues the devs finally did add - such as tile-edge match highlighting - are very difficult to see.

Overall, the game is fun and relaxing, unless you need to strain your eyes and/or can't constantly hold down the left-shift key for hours on end.

So thumbs-up for the great concept.
Thumbs-down for not even trying to accommodate accessibility needs after nearly two years of being live.

This game highlights the problem with Steam's yes or no system.
The game is painfully repetitive, and within two hours you've pretty much seen and done all there is to it. Yes, you might unlock a new tile that serves no purpose at some future point, or even an equally purposeless different colour scheme, but you can't work towards it because you have no idea what specific action beyond "Complete a quest" will do so.
Dorfromantic is essentially 6-sided dominoes with pictures instead of dots. It's easy enough for a 5 year old to pick up in 5 minutes, but the tactics and concentration can take MUCH longer to master.
The game's repetition is its greatest flaw, but much as I found it unimaginative to play, there's something beautiful and mesmerising about it. The gentle music and the cute little landscapes had me thinking about the game FAR more than I actually played it. They combine to create something truly blissful. That said, the concentration and tactics required to master it are not at all relaxing - in fact, it's more like a stressful exam. The game depends upon what appears to be random tiles, but that randomness can also be your downfall where, no matter how flawlessly you play, you may simply never receive the tiles you need to attain the high scores or unlock more cards or specials.
I would give this a 7 out of 10 if Steam had scores, and it's great to see Toukana continuing to enhance it. I WOULD buy this again, especially at just ¬£7.69, but it's all about the atmosphere, not the game play.
game good

Such a simple concept.
Start with a number of 6 sided puzzle pieces and an empty board with 1 starting piece.
Place your puzzle piece one by one on the board connecting them.
Each side of the piece can be water, trees, house, railroad track, water, corn field.
You can connect trees and a house, but that is only when you have no other options.
Place them so ideal as possible and make the country you are creating as big as possible.
Some pieces have tasks attached, for example grow a town as big as 500 houses.
When you complete these tasks you receive extra pieces to place.
Go as far as possible until you have no more pieces to place.

Very addictive and perfect for spending some free time to fill.

It's a wonderful way to spend time letting your mind disconnect for the day and enjoy building a landscape and making tiles fit together... No pressure, no stress... just relax and let your creativity flow.

I haven't played much of it, but the times I have played it-- when I'm just kind of staring at my game library, unsure of what to play within a short window, but don't want to be stressed out-- it's been a cup of warm tea.

I like this game a normal amount.

Legitimately easy to lose yourself in and has that difficult-to-strike balance of easy to learn, hard to master, imo. The tile-placing gets more understandable and potentially more complex as you keep playing -- if you want to get a big score, that is. The visuals are incredibly charming. All in all, a game that's easy to sink into and just relax with. It is one of my all time favorites, thank you Toukana Interactive! Danke sch√∂n!

You ever played Carcassone, a boardgame about earning points by placing tiles? You know, you get a tile per turn, you gotta place it in ways that would help you secure more points. This is literally it but with hexagons and singleplayer, and more freeform - and because there's no other player competing for the meeple figurine placement, there's way more creativity involved to make a prettier landscape. Also, no meeple placement either.

This one can be both seriously challenging if you feel like going for high scores, and at same time super comforting, allowing you to create endearingly comforting rural landscapes with towns, railways and rivers. There's some unlocking to do trough achievements too, adding new visual bits, and those may take time but aren't that super tough to actually secure, since the game is really gripping so it's a matter of time till you unlock everything.

Of you enjoy relaxing tile placement at any capacity, go ahead, buy it!

Great game when you need to chill and relax, landscapes are growing little by little and end being beautiful, having a gigantic map near the end is really satisfying. Sound ambiance is also a great point for relaxing.
Great, beautiful and so relaxing but... I am extremely disappointed that this game is not intended for macOS. changed my laptop and can't play it anymore :(
Quick and simple world builder - satisfying.

When I bought this Game (quite early After Release!) I suspect to habe a basic puzzle game. After about 40-50h in this Game I have to say , it's my favorit puzzle game where you can perfectly relax and calm down. OMG this soundtrack is so awesome. It's one of these games, I played ALWAYS with sound! My normal behavior is like instantly mute music in Games and turn down the volume for sound effects. 
After a longer pause from this game I kind of discovered it again and WOW even in my head it was fully underated. I even realized I am we're playing it the wrong way and learned how to score better highsores... It is even quite nice on the Steam Deck! 

Additionaly there is the fact that it won the Steam Awards multipe times. Will be one of my favorit games 4ever <3
YES VERRY GOOD :))

I find myself continually coming back to this game. I'll admit, part its to try and beat my sons high score, though mainly its because its just so nice!  
Wake up, cup a tea, tai chi, placing some tiles and making a massive forest on Dorf. Great way to start the day.

This game is a really great way to just turn your brain off, take in the cool art style, and relax.
But like it's also an "overthink every move and spend 100 hours trying to just be okay at this stupid game," kind of strategy game.

100% recommend, great to just pass a few minutes or to kill a few hours.
Amazing puzzle game endlessly re-playable. Beautiful art style

I love relaxing with this game and the critters that I unlock are such a treat for me. I enjoy the peaceful nature of this game. I appreciate the goal that the developers set out to accomplish to just have a nice game to play.

This is currently the most relaxing game that I own. Whether you're doing the challenges, or infinite, you can really vibe out while listening to some music or watching a video. 

I do wish there were more unique tiles though. Perhaps workshop support could add some unique features to the game.
This is good game to relax.

Good and extremely calming game but it's really not for me. It's repetitive and actually really hard, might just be me though.

I'd say, buy it, test it out, refund if you don't like it.

Addictive puzzle game disguised as a simple city builder, providing the challenge of the former and pleasant atmosphere of the latter.

7.0/10
A chill experience if you want to cool down from getting the kids to nap time.

Amazing atmosphere, great game if you want to spend 15-30 minutes absolutely vibing (longer if you're better than me). The limited tile and quest mechanics make it just challenging enough that you don't feel like you're wasting time, but it's not so hard that you need a break. Perfect balance, could spend years of my life playing this.

So, if you like puzzles and are looking for a game to help you relax after a stressful day THIS IS IT!  Its puzzle meets dominoes where you try to match the sides of your hexagons with the surrounding tiles to make a beautiful landscape. Very simple puzzle game. You can make it as difficult as you want. You could literally place tiles anywhere or you can challenge yourself by trying to complete objectives, match as many sides as possible and unlock new tiles and features.  No pressure. if you like puzzles you will love this. The music is so soothing I had to try to stay awake. Get it on sale!
nice and relaxing
Legit enjoyable

Did you know that Dorfromantik is actually German for 'wholesome'? The very concept of the game itself is in fact an epitome of Dorfromantik, not only for its aesthetic proficiency and sensuous delight, but also in its ability to execute a perfect balance between the aspects of challenge and stimulus, creating a most enjoyable and relaxing gameplay experience. If you believe that you might be worthy of knowing what Dorfromantik truly means, playing this game is your next step in life.
gg
I play this during work meetings.

There are just too many technical issues with this game.

- It picks the wrong monitor and screen resolution.
- Once I switched to windowed mode it confused the width and height of the monitor and made the window high instead of wide.
- The drop down for screen resolution collapses into a list of one character gibberish instead of showing the proper resolutions.
- After I played it in Windowed mode for a few minutes I noticed that the GPU is running full tilt. This game seems to stress my nvidia 3080 harder than most modern games like Battlefield.
- Just a few minutes into the game the screen goes black and the game crashes.
My OCD is pleased
Mesmerizing
Zen AF and amazing on steam deck
This game is a lot of fun!
very chill mouse only game with a very calming soundtrack and a great way to kill some downtime

I quite like the zen feeling I get from playing this game, it doesn't rush you can you can play as fast or slow as you'd like. The animations of the different tiles are adorable as well, overall just a lovely tile placing game. Fully recommend!
fun

A solid game and I want to give the devs credit for a nice piece of art they've created.  Ultimately I refunded it because the pace and core gameplay are not my jam, yet I can't deny the value of the game itself.

All said, do I recommend Dorfromantik? Yes. Absolutely. The simple premise of placing hexagonal tiles to match their neighbour is so easily understood, but immensely satisfying. There‚Äôs even a splash of hidden depth in the experience for players that want to plan ahead to pull off crazy wombo-combos of perfect tile placements. Dorfromantik is an easy game to recommend, and one of 2022‚Äôs finest. It‚Äôs well worth your while to check it out, especially if you‚Äôre in the market for a chilled out puzzler that‚Äôll let you achieve Zen-like nirvana.

More at: https://frostilyte.ca/2022/07/18/dorfromantik-review/
If you have just a tiny bit of OCD, don't get this game. It will just drive you up the freaking wall.
Pretty chill, with enough mechanics to learn to stay interesting.
Just relaxing experience. Beautiful game
Extremely good and calming game, I love it.
Great game, very relaxing and a great mind teaser!

A very relaxing game, great to unwind. Doesn't require a lot of thinking Either, which is great after a hard day at work. Music is also relaxing to listen too with nature sounds and instrumental music, Birds chirping, wind sounds and grass  moving. I recommend!

I've been playing this fairly frequently, little bursts at a time after work etc. 

its good, its relaxing and simple while still maintaining a challenge to encourage you to both focus on and enjoy, there's also a creative mode which I've used maybe once? it looks good i'm just content at the moment with the straight challenge side of things for now. 

good if you're prone to anxiety or high stress during the day and need a distraction away from it all however long you need, the music and sounds add to the relaxing environment of it all and help immerse you into the little world you're building.

I play some intense games. I play kenshi, i play project zomboid,  I play solo rust because i'm an absolute masochist. Sometimes I need something different, something super chill. So I turn to Dorfromantik, vibe out and put down some hexagons and feel right as rain. Games can be stressful, chaotic and anxiety inducing but Dorfromantik is none of that. Dorfromantik is my pre-bedtime cool down game. Pure zen vibes.
Super chill and really fun
A very chill game, especially the soundtrack.  Easy to learn and tricky to play well.  One thing you can unlock is trains, and the hex tiles makes for some funky track layouts

Just one more tile.


This game is so chill and simple yet complicated and addicting. 
You get a stack of tiles, you then place the titles to match and gain points. Byt matching all sides you get more tiles and by completing objectives you also gain more with the goal of going for as long as possible. 
It's a solid simple tittle that I have sunk far too much time into and will continue to.

Pros: A fun, relaxing minimal city-builder, in vein of similar titles like ISLANDERS. Offers a decent level of challenge, and has a decent collection of sound design and soundtrack elements.

Cons: Unlocks and progression are somewhat repetitive and limited, making the experience a bit slow after some initial hours of gameplay.
fun and relaxing
very calming game
Super chill game that you can switch off with. Hours of tile spinning go by so quickly that you won't realise you've played all day.
nice

A nice, chill, puzzle game that catches you with the "just one more time" until you realize you've been playing all day. Easy, but still challenging to plan out your village in a way that won't mess you up later.
This is my favorite game to relax with after a hard day. I can just chill and create something new every time. very satisfying. 10/10
so calm and relaxing
Truly one of the most satisfying games I've ever played! worth every penny
Great game, only thing thats not optimal is the way achievements work. Other than that this is an amazing, relaxing game.

If you want to chill and at the same time use your brain this game is perfect. Soundtrack is relaxing and if you have a steam deck you can continu wherever you want.  I have to admit this a great value for the money.

A perfect little puzzle game for low-stress, zen-like play, it's all so adorable and easy to lose yourself in the process of building up your little forests, villages, railroads, fields and waterways.

Great relaxing game with plenty of strategy and lots of aesthetic appeal.  It's a lot like a video game version of Carcassonne.  Multiple modes to add variety.  Good for either longer or shorter play sessions.
addictive!

I don't get why people find it so relaxing and satisfying. Nothing happens. Yeah it looks cute but you can't interact with the world at all and maybe I'm just bad but its more frustrating than anything else to me because you'll rarely get those perfectly matching blocks. If you are into relaxing puzzle style games then Dorfromantik is for you.  It is not a city simulation it is just a nice relaxing puzzle game with a number of different modes to challenge your creativity and puzzle solving skills.

Super relaxing, great music.  It's a simple game to enjoy while winding down, to help clear your mind and just enjoy.

Its purspose and mechanics are simple yet it presents and delivers everything amazingly. You are going to get addicted real fast and without knowing it.
Art and music fit perfectly to the vibes of the game.

Developers were kind and thoughtful enough to let you actually continue buliding your world, even after you finish the session, in the creative mode. That was so nice of them.

I suffer from PTSD, anxiety, and depression and this game helps me when I'm feeling low, or having a moment.   I recommend it to people with normal brains too.   Calm and stress free city builder,  fun to pick up for 5 minutes or to sink a few hours into.

chill but challenging to a point. Requires attention but not so much that you can't listen to a podcast or some such thing.

I didn't think I'd like this game, but I did think it looked peaceful and cute. The art style and music are really appealing. But when it went on sale I picked it up, and wow! It's a total blast! I get sucked right into the puzzle of matching the tiles and looking around the map. I love the little details, like the swans swimming, or the trains and boats. The smoke coming from the houses, and unlocking the new biomes. Just a really lovely game. More than got my money's worth already, and I'm certainly not finished enjoying the game.

I love this game. Fun, pretty, low pressure, chill vibes!! Can just pick it up and play to relax or kill some time.

It's a great adaptation of the physical game. The different tile sets and individual tile skins that you can unlock are great but not necessary.  It's addicting and creative and each game is different.
I feel like I am doing so much and absolutely nothing at the same time and it is wonderful. Beautiful game. 10 out of 10

Dor-Fro-Mantik is fun relaxing puzzle/building simulator.   Basic concept is to fit pieces of "land" in the most efficient way to maximize your score.   Their are achievements based on your score and requirements met that unlock unique pieces of land.  If you are looking for something chill you can hop on and play for 30 minutes and hop off.  This is it!

It looks pretty but it's not particularly entertaining (my gran might enjoy it) and for some reason makes my computer work harder than AAA games. Tried to make myself play it but lost interest and gave up.

The menu system is awful. You cannot for example click 'new game,'  'quit game,' 'load/save game' or 'game mode' from the main menu. But you can select 'continue game' from the main menu.

These options exist in a schizophrenic patchwork of different panels and entirely separate menus. It requires an exploratory search multiple times until you've successfully overwritten your knowledge of how games work.

The game mechanics are entertaining, and the graphic style is pleasant.

Fun and stress free game.
Would recommend.

Really relaxing puzzle game. Makes my brain go brrrr.

Beautiful and Charming. Tiles go down, numbers go up. This game is like a hot cup of coffee on a cold morning. It captures the feel of the first few turns exploring in a civ game without having to play a whole game of civ.
Great relaxing game. Each round in normal mode takes about an hour or so.

Definitely a fun and peaceful countryside building game. I would say that it is definitely worth the price if your looking for something relaxing to play, but don't expect a lot of gameplay and strategy.

This is such a peaceful, relaxing game. There are just enough strategy and puzzle elements to keep the game from being "brainless", while the quests keep the game interesting.

I wasn't sure if I would like Dorfromantik at first, as I generally prefer action and tactical games over 'relaxing games', but I soon found it to be surprisingly challenging and addictive, despite its premise of being a relaxing game. This is because the game incentivises multiple playthroughs by providing you with challenges that gradually unlock new tile pieces, tile skins, and biomes.

If you want to play a city builder game without the potential stress of managing resources, population, food, or other similar statistics, then this might be the game for you.
turbo chill

It may not seem like much at first, but this simple puzzle game can keep you busy. You can just to sit back, relax, and go on autopilot without having to think about anything for a while. It does cost quite a bit, so waiting for a discount is worth it.

Chill game, cute aesthetic, and it's fun trying to get perfect matches only. It can be enjoyed both playing casually and not really thinking too much as well as trying to go for an insane score. I love discovering new tile types and it's nice to put on a podcast, music, or a stream in the background while I play.

I feel like I'm Bob Ross playing a video game. Planting happy little trees in my landscape. Probably the most chill game I've ever played and I've only been playing a few hours. When you're tired of shoot 'em ups, multiplayer toxicity, or figuring out how to exploit crappy AI, come to this game and forget about it all. 10/10.

Incredibly relaxing game with an addicting tile placing premise and darling details. It's my favorite game to wind down with after a stressful day and also something cheerful to play on a lazy afternoon.
Relaxing and beautiful. Great casual puzzle game. Top Tier.
Very relaxing. 10/10
Damn trains!
This game is so relaxing and fun, the perfect game to play after work while you watch YouTube, and the replay value is through the roof.
Absolute perfect game to play when coming down from a panic attack.
Very relaxing, love the music and trying to beat my own high score never gets old.
fun game

it's very chill, you can just put down tiles, or you can think about every move as long as you want. I love how easily you get into the rhythm and just play. Visually, the game is pretty, it is simple and easy to understand, and the small boats and trains that go around are nice touches. The different biomes and colours give it a variety that's very pleasing to the eye. Definitely recommended!
Goodbye life.
Such a relaxing game; it's perfect for winding down a bit at the end of the day. It's also simple and satisfying (at times), get it and see for yourself!
This game is more interesting than I thought. Chill and relaxing game, but still forces the last cell of your brain to work.

It reminds me of a solo Carcasonne without the competitive part. Just a relaxed placing of tiles to build a beautiful landscape. Even if you misplace tiles, like Bob Ross would say: "There are no mistakes just happy accidents".

Game is very simple yet extremely challenging if you want it to be. I love the art style and its super fun making the landscapes while doing the "quests". Found myself enjoying this way more then I thought I would! 9/10

If you like a puzzle game which requires thinking, structure and order, then this is the game for you.
The concept is relatively simple, you put puzzle pieces together (grass / houses / water / rail / farmland / forest) and you score points for putting them in the correct spot.
 
It is one of those games that you'll either find relaxing and peaceful or you'll get frustrated by not having the puzzle pieces in place. You do a lot better when you take your time and in the right frame of mind. 

This is a game that only the Germans could develop. You'll understand why if you play it long enough.
v chill. perfect wind down game before bed.
magikal
definitely more addicting than heroin
This game is incredibly relaxing and so pretty. I easily lost 3 hours the other day playing it.
There is very little in terms of a game. It is a good title for kids but there are small games that I like way more. Mechanically it is fine but it feels like there needs to be more to do.
One of the most relaxing games on Steam. Go at your own pace, build a beautiful little toy world. Appreciate the little things.
This is a very chill world-building tile-laying game. I can't stop playing it.

I love Carcassonne so as soon as I saw this game I knew I had to pick it up! It's fun and very casual but there are times where I do find myself getting bored and quitting, but I always come back to it. I definitely think it's worth the purchase.

Dorfromantik is a simple and yet addicting world builder that provides you with random puzzle pieces that you have to use to create a world however you must be smart with your placement as your next set of pieces relies on the utilisation of prior pieces

Try and get the highest score by utilising the map, pieces and unlocks to your advantage.
This is worth a full price purchase in my opinion, if you can get it on sale even better!
perfect game to go head empty

[h1] Simply amazing [/h1]

I can't think of a single negative thing to say about this game. The gameplay could be called repetitive, yet I seem to be physically unable to put it down. The artstyle is beautiful, the music soothes my core, and the gameplay is so simple yet challenging. The feeling of getting that perfect fitting tile or filling that one gap that had been bothering you forever cannot be beat. Please pick this game up and show it some love!!

When you need a break from thieving, cheating, mayhem and murder. When you want to lay back in your chair and just use your mouse, while you rest your gaming hand or shovel food into your gullet. Well, this is that time. It's a nice change of pace when you need it. A puzzle game that feels alive with a cute art style. Highly Recommend.

I can't get enough of this game! I literally just played 2 rounds, quit the game, and launched it again to play two more. 
I heard of it on 9gag and bought it shortly after. If your first association is with Carcassone - you're right! The core of the game is very similar - you are placing hexagon tiles next to each other so they can create large spaces of fields, forests, or towns. The biggest difference - your goal is to keep playing as long as you can. Placing perfectly matched tiles, doing challenges and tasks, and managing what's worth doing and what is not. 

Pros:
- So pretty. As the map grows it only gets more charming and more "real". The graphic style reminds me of Don't Starve (it's something about the trees)
- Simple yet challenging mechanics
- "Another round" syndrome hits hard
- Perfect as a short break

Those few tiny cons:
- Music get's monotonous
- Background colors sometimes flicker
- RNG is an arse sometimes but it's understandable.

Big congrats to Devs and good luck with further updates!
The most casual and pretty mind puzzle game I've ever played. Discovering it is playful and mastering it is difficult
Great game, wonderful ambient music and beautiful tiles. Really enjoying this and definitely recommend.

This is my favorite chilling game, and its time i gave it a review! 
I have been playing this since it was in Early Access, and i quickly fell in love with the game!

This game is for the player that enjoys a relaxing puzzle, with or without a challenge, sandbox mode and achievements. 
Many achievements are unlocked just by playing the game, and within a game session you have 3 goals that you can try and reach, this gives you something to try and build towards, as it can otherwise be overwhelming to have free hands, these goals changes (as far as i remember) when you reach one. Some of them have to be reached in one sitting, if these aren't reached, that goal changes so you can try out something else, others can be reached over multiple game sessions and will often stay until completed.

This tile puzzle game have a super cute and relaxing atmosphere, chill music and sounds, and i find myself exited to unlock the next "bear in woods" - skin or a new windmill skin. I challenge myself to try and mach most tiles or make a pretty river though the landscape. Its a game for people who wants to just chill out and relax with some cozy puzzling and if you need a pause from the big AAA games, this is a game i can see most people play to just do something different.

It was worth the money and i would even pay for it again on my switch, where i can see it as a great travel game!

[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
It looks like the Catan games; but now it is just a relaxed building mode. You have a stack of tiles. You need to connect the tiles with the same sides to score points and fulfil quests. If you are successful, you will be able to unlock new tiles, get more achievements and you are rewarded with more tiles so you can get a higher score. However, first and foremost is to chill and relax. It has helped me to get back on my feet after a challenging period in my life. It's nice to play for 30 minutes or so at a time when you want to wind down and the result is a lovely landscape all build by you. 

[H1]The good[/H1]
The art style is great; the music is relaxing and the little effects are cute. I really like it. Performance is great.

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
I suppose if I have to nit-pick: some of the achievements are hard to get. But then again if you are that good in the game that you can manage to get them you deserve full respect.

The achievements are not transparent in how to unlock them (you need to complete the "Star mission" in game before the Steam achievements will unlock). 

[H1]Summary[/H1]
If you're looking for a chill game puzzle game to help you unwind I can highly recommend it. I've played it a lot and it has grown on me: it's now one of my favourite games.
I've been playing since launch and its really fun and creative. It challenges the mind to think and its a great game to pass time or when your waiting for other things.
Love this game! It's so addictive trying to build your world larger each time and collecting all the different tile pieces.  And the music is nice and relaxing

[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]

TLDR: So peaceful, gentle, and relaxing. 

So I absolutely played Dorf Romantik incorrectly.
Now anyone who‚Äôs played a single minute of this game will be scratching their heads at that. ‚ÄúWhat? How did you manage that?!‚Äù I can hear them ask. 

Simply put: I played to win. That is not how the game is meant to be played, and DR did everything it could to show me that. Being the hard headed fool that I am, I didn‚Äôt listen until too late. 
Dorf Romantik is all about the journey. There is no winning, there is only going as far as you can, and trying to love what you‚Äôve built along the way. 
The game has you placing tiles to design a map. Rotate them, match sides, spread out, uncover secret tiles, and complete quests to earn more tiles to place. That‚Äôs it. There is no story, there are no enemies, and there isn‚Äôt a higher purpose. It just‚Ä¶ is. 

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Peaceful in a way that most games simply aren‚Äôt. If you allow yourself to get lost in the ambiance, focus on the puzzle aspect, and just let the world go, you can be comfortable for a while. 
[*] The music, ambient noises, and artwork are lovely. They‚Äôre fitting and relaxing. 
[*] This has a one more tile, one more game, or one more hour type of addictive play.
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] The tile unlock system is tied into the achievement unlock system, which is tied itself to quests given by the mystery tiles. This is VERY poorly explained in game, and the moment I realised I needed to achieve to unlock more tiles I began hammering the achievements, only to find they weren‚Äôt unlocking because I had to unlock the achievements options by completing mystery quests‚Ä¶ this was so convoluted and unintuitive that I can only describe it as ‚Äòfrustrating‚Äô. 
[*] There is no way to turn off some of the unlocks. For example I really didn‚Äôt enjoy building in the ‚Äònight‚Äô zone. The grey made it hard to see, the tiles just weren‚Äôt as nice in my opinion, and I found the experience off-putting. That it keeps pushing itself into my game, forcing me to move away from promising developments or breaking my flow is not a pleasant experience. 
[*] This isn‚Äôt really a game, as I‚Äôve come to expect. No levels or real measurable progress. While I very much love it, I can‚Äôt help but feel like it‚Äôs missing something. But that just feeds back into my opening statement, really. I‚Äôve come with the wrong mind-set. Nothing makes this clearer than every achievement complete, and no maps saved. 
[/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]
 [list][*] A title swapper. Allowing you to change out a rouge tile placed for necessity earlier with the perfect tile later (but not if it would undo a quest or take tiles away from you).
[*] A tile painter, allowing you to ‚Äòpaint‚Äô a terrain type on a tile edge. 
[*] More variety. New quests (link areas, functional settlements, rotations challenge), new tiles (bridges? train stations? harbours?), but also controls to turn on and off the unlocked content that we like. 
[/list]


[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]

If you‚Äôre a so-called ‚Äòtype A‚Äô person, I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôll enjoy this. An old web comic of a ‚Äòtype A‚Äô guy being told to calm down and smell the flowers taking it too far and winning a most flowers sniffed trophy comes to mind. This isn‚Äôt that sort of game. 
If you want structure and meaning, this also isn‚Äôt for you. 
If RNG hates you, then this game is going to be a slog. 
If you want stories or plot or high octane explosive fun, it‚Äôs got none‚Ä¶
But if you want peace? If you like puzzles and map builders, want something gentle, relaxing, and I guess sort of old school? Then you‚Äôre in luck. 
I played this game incorrectly. But I‚Äôd like to hope that when I want to chill out, it comes back into my mind, so that I play it the way it was intended in the future.

There is 0 grind, 0 levels, 0 management. Each session is self contained, you're going for high score. I've finally cracked the top 100k on the leader-boards. This game is amazing: calming, entertaining, and though provoking. 

The worlds you build are beautiful, every game is different, and overtime you're going to learn which pieces "should" go together instinctively. The hardest part for me is always remembering to close off my missions to get more cards. 

Definitely give this game a try if youre itching for something different and unique. You won't be disappointed.

This game is simple, fun and so very addictive, it's almost terrifying. It's also really easy to learn and to just jump into. Strangely enough, it can be relaxing [i]and[/i] brain-wracking at the same time, which makes for something of a unique experience. 

The point, very briefly explained, is to place six-sided tiles on the map and try to get them to match with the tiles you will place next to them. You get points based on how well you achieve this. The more you play and more points you earn, the more special tiles you unlock, keeping things interesting. You also get to decide the pace. You can spend hours and hours creating that perfect landscape in the creative mode or you can choose to go for the more challenging game modes (which, admittedly, can still take hours). 

After a couple of days of playing, I'm quite certain this will become my go-to game whenever I need to scratch that itch to build or create something. Considering this game's immense replay value and low price, I would say it's quite a steal. Get yours now!

It's cute, it's addicting, it just isn't any fun to play. In 10 hours of play I never once had a single minute of fun. I never once sat back at the end of a game and said, "Wow, look at this nice city." All cities end up disjointed and look fake and wrong, even with tons of perfect matches, and there's no incentive to play at all beyond unlocking new cosmetic pieces.

And referring to this as any kind of "city builder" is flat out misrepresentation -- it's a puzzle edge matching game with city building pieces. No city building concepts exist in this barebones time waster, and it's a barebones time waster that contradicts its own rules constantly. I was repeatedly able to extend my current game on the last piece available by randomly placing the piece until the game invisibly and nonsensically decided I should get more new pieces because I placed that piece there. It doesn't make sense, even per its own rules and tutorial which I did fully play.

Maybe a patch or mods can help this one become something someday, but all I'll remember about this game going forward is how much time I wasted trying to like it.

For everyone who struggles with highscores: Perfect placements are VERY important as you get one card back each time you score one. Time closing your areas well, at best after you collected some flags in them that give you extra cards on top.

As I was running out of tiles, I found myself probing and cancelling all kinds of moves more and more desperately in order to get at least some tiles. As tile number dropped to single digits and game music became more intense, I frantically moved my screen all around, scavenging for any last match I could use. Just one more turn, just one more tile.
Then it occurred to me. Is that not what I was doing for all those years? I know I can't win in this game. I know I was never supposed to. Struggle all you want, ending is the same for everyone. So why bother? Why continue to fight the inevitable?
I swallowed the cold air and put down another tile. That gave me just enough to struggle for another turn.

So the game overall is nice and instigates important existential questions, but I'm not so sure about the 'relaxing' tag.

If you are looking for a game that is "fun" I don't think that this would fit the description for many people. It is a puzzle game that isn't really all that much of a puzzle. You have fields, farms, forests, and village tiles that will only give you points if you connect them to tiles the same type. Then you have rails and rivers, that can only be attached (at certain angles) to tiles of the same type.

That is it really. Connect them perfectly on all six sides and you will get extra bonus points and more tiles to keep building with. Honestly, combined with the in-game music, or your own soothing tunes, this can be a really calming experience.

I would recommend it, but again, only to a certain type of person who is looking for a very specific gaming, almost meditative, experience.

UPDATED AFTER FULL RELEASE

Dorfromantik has been a joy to play this past year. 

The formula is perfect for whatever you want to get out of it. If you want a relaxing domino-style town builder, you've got it. If you want an intense, puzzle-forward game where you race for that highscore, you've got it. If you want a neat little tool to design settlements and experiment with making beautiful landscapes, you've got it. Toukana seriously thought of everything.

All of the biomes are stunning -- my favourites have to be the Enchanted and Sakura ones. The music never fails to blow me away, and the sound design is supremely satisfying. 

I have high hopes for Toukana going forward, and for this game with the Steam Awards coming soon. It deserves recognition for everything it has achieved. Definitely worth the purchase, at full price or otherwise

This is my go-to game when I wanna do some chill gaming but still want something engaging and challenging. How "hard" it is really just depends on how interested you are on getting a high score, and then how motivated you are in trying to beat your high scores.  

The "deck" of tiles are finite meaning your game ends when you run out, but you gain more by completing tasks (connecting a certain number of a type of tile, such as a railroad, a river, a forest, a town, or a meadow), but your score is multiplied by how many matching sides you create EG you may be focusing on completing your 15 tile railroad but each tile also has 6 sides, and so ideally you want to complete your railroad task only/mostly by placing railroad tiles that also match as the other sides - you'll be torn between perfection and efficiency. This means you have to use some foresight when placing tiles so that you set yourself up for success and don't accidentally lock yourself into an area such that you can't complete a task IE by overlapping tasks that then require very specific tiles to complete both.  You want to diversify your placement a bit so that you have options and get the best score with each tile, but you also want to complete tasks so you can get more tiles.  It becomes incredibly satisfying when you not only keep your score climbing but you see your sprawling city stretching into different biomes, forming interesting patterns and such.

Sometimes I don't play for a couple months and might have been spending my time in more high intensity games, but there are days when I will start a Dorfromantik game and literally spend hours just on one game.

I absolutely love Dorfromantik!  It's so simple to play, I can just sit and chill to play when I need to relax, yet it doesn't feel repetitive or boring.   I love strategy games and especially love when I can find the kind I can play without straining my brain when I'm just needing something to do to destress when I'm feeling tired.

Full disclosure: I only played this game through the tutorial and about half of one game.  Maybe I would like it a bit better after more stuff was unlocked.  But I just couldn't get into it.  I was so bored I couldn't even complete that one game.  It's basically like a solitaire version of the board game Carcassonne, with significantly more simplistic and arbitrary rules.  The big objectives just come up at random at different points in the game, making long-term strategy impossible.  It has so little strategy or thinking that I wouldn't even really describe it as a puzzle game.  It's more like relaxing into a Zen-like mode by doing simple repetitive tasks in a visually-pleasing environment.  If that's what you want, you might like it.  But if you want a puzzle game that tests your brain, stay away from this.

I can't recommend Dorfromantik. The graphics and peaceful music really appealled to me at first, but the "classic" puzzles are too hard. You start with 40 tiles in your stack; each one contains a mixture of different elements (houses, grass, grain fields, water, trees and train tracks). Once you run out of tiles you lose. To replenish your stack you have to complete one of two objectives:
1) Link a certain number of elements together (5 trees, 9 houses, 14 railway tracks etc)
2) Match every tile you lay down perfectly with its six neighbors. This only gives you one additional tile.
Sounds easy and fun, right? Wrong! You can only view the two top tiles in your stack, so you can't really plan ahead. And you will run out of tiles no matter how diligently you play - because your stack is entirely random. I tried focusing on either objective or mixing both and I still lost time after time. And that peaceful appeal of the graphics and game? Lost in the process.
Been playing this since release. It's such a cute, calming game. Highly recommend for a game that makes you think without frustration!

[u]TLDR[/u]

Get it, it's good.

[u]The What[/u]

It's a game where you place hexagonal tiles next to each other, unlocking more tiles as you complete objective tiles by connecting a certain number of tiles together.

[u]The Good[/u]

The graphics are gorgeous, the soundtrack is incredibly chill and soothing and the game is pleasant and relaxing to play.

[u]The Bad[/u]

You will look at the clock and realise that it's 4AM.

[u]The Meh[/u]

Some tiles are difficult to place and don't really fit in anywhere.

After only playing it 2-3 hours I looked it up on the internet and made reservations for the physical board game version which is coming soon. That one will be for 1-6 players cooperatively, while this digital version is just for 1 player. I wish they would implement a 2 player online co-op mode that you can share the experience and thereby make it three times as lovely.

What this digital version has, which the board game version will not, is the music, the 3D tiles with little buildings and fields, and the 3D animations such like moving boats, trains and birds that fly around.

TL;DR - an incredibly relaxing game you will accidentally lose hours of your life in, but unfortunately, losing sometimes feels out of your control.

The game is structured around completing missions that are attached to hexagonal tiles you're issued, usually in the form of connecting a certain number of tiles of a given type together. When you complete a mission, you are given additional tiles, extending how long your game can run. As you get further along, the missions become harder, and so it becomes increasingly important to get perfect placements to earn more pieces instead. However, many of your runs will end waiting on the random number generator to give you the right tile to fill a space, and instead fighting to find a place for a complex railway intersection tile. Also, some details of the game that are important for having longer-running playthroughs are never told to you. For instance, you can only have so many active missions at once, and so in some cases, it's important to deliberately terminate missions that are too difficult to complete.

There are multiple game modes, including a custom game mode that lets you tailor the proportions of tile types for your playthrough to make it easier on yourself, or to create a challenge, which you can share with your friends. They also have a monthly mode, offering unique challenges to compete with others on.

Achievements are handled in a somewhat unique manner, in that you can only achieve them when they are one of your three assigned achievement missions for a playthrough, and you can't earn higher-ranked achievements at the same time as the lower-ranked ones. And don't expect to get them easily - towards the end, achievements require each to be your playthrough's central focus, and they can't be earned in the custom game mode. Each achievement you earn also unlocks a unique decorative tile that the game will sometimes issue instead of the basic version.

The music is pleasant, and doesn't really get old. The art is simple, but varied enough to make things interesting. Complaints are minimal. I highly recommend this game.

And tiny little animals, yes please.

I'm sure many others have said this, but it bears repeating. This game is so chill. So perfectly chill. I've only played about 10 hours, but it really feels like so much more, mainly because I play a little bit here and there and feel so relaxed after playing a round. It's a little like game therapy. Which is what the game designer's intention was, apparently. 

The graphics are clean and pretty, with an eye to detail when you zoom in, though it's not busy. There is some movement, windmills gently spinning, clouds drifting lazily, boats chugging in the water - this all adds to the peaceful ambiance. The color palette is warm and soothing.

The game play is fairly simple, reminding me of Carcassonne with some of its expansions added in. It is possible to really focus on strategy as far as where you place pieces. The level of commitment is entirely up to the player. Sometimes it's nice to place pieces just to make a cool design, but if one plays with an eye towards completing various goals that pop up with different pieces, the game begins to open up with unlockables that include new pieces and goals. Some of these goals include growing bigger forests, rivers or farmlands. There is a lot of luck involved in which pieces you'll draw from your pile next, which is sometimes frustrating if you are looking for a particular piece. For my play style, this isn't a big deal. I like completing the goals, but they are not my main focus, which is really just winding down from a hectic day.

This might not be the most played game in your library, but I guarantee it will chill you out, assuming that is what you're looking for. Of note, the developer is constantly updating the game with cool little additions. New tiles and themes have been released on a pretty steady basis. I find that whenever I fire it up, there are always new touches that surprise me and add to my enjoyment.

For me, a thumbs up is the perfect rating system. This is a 10/10 game, a 100/100, even! Shucks, I'd sell my middle child for this game. I think you'd have to be a monster to not enjoy this game on some level. Even a monster should enjoy it, methinks.

Dorfromantik is a decent pick-up-anytime puzzle game if you just want to chill for a moment. The concept is very straightforward: try to match the same sides as much as you can and make all the forests, fields, rivers, railroads, etc... as big/long as you can or until you reached the required number. A bit like the boardgame Carcassonne, though you are allowed to mismatch. You are limited on pieces, but you can earn more pieces by finishing goals and making multiple matches with a single piece, which could make the game go on endlessly.
The game has a lot of achievements, but you can't just go for them until you have unlocked being able to do them, which is randomly decided when connecting to a special piece. It gives the game a little bit of a challenge and a goal besides just going for the highest score.
Other than that, there's not much to do in this game besides trying to make patterns or such, so it is not for everyone and can get boring after just a few games if you want more of a challenge. Still, even at the full price, it is worth a go!

This game has become the one that I play to have some me time, to relax and to do things I love. It's as challenging as you want it to be with the different options there are within the game. Even if you challenge yourself by playing it with a limit, you can always continue your map in the creative mode, which gives it a gorgeous twist on being creative in your own way. 

Wether you play this every day or decide to not look at it for a while, it will always be a game that will relax you in a way that it doesn't give you any pressure to achieve things. However, the achievements do make you think twice about placing something and only adds creativity in your brain.

As you can hear, I'm hooked. I can only hope you'll like this as much as I do :)
