It amazes me how such an uncomplicated game can be so not boring. The gameplay is very easy to learn and is rewarding very quickly. As straightforward as it is - there's a great variety in which it can be played... achievement hunting, casual quest completing, fun 'exploration', high score, town/landscape sculpturing, etc. And the beautiful part is that you don't have to 'pick' a method/goal each time you go to play it. The goal is enjoying the game - and how you get to that destination is completely fluid, based on your mood and choices, and you can swap your strategy around several times within a single gameplay. It's really all about having a good time. 
My other comment is on the graphics and music... I can't say thank you enough to the devs for giving us such a peaceful, charming and pleasing environment. It's hard finding an honest to goodness 'relax and enjoy' kind of game (esp for a strategist) - but finding a game where the graphics are not painful or offensive is... breathtakingly refreshing. 
In a word, I have found Dorfromantik to be a sweet, simple, priceless gem of a game that is very endearing. God bless all the devs for providing the community with such a treasure!
P.S. I haven't' fiddled much yet with the 'creative' option (maybe only in early access as of this review) - but it looks like a really nice outlet for those unrequited needs to build and create! A definite plus for those with that inclination.
P.P.S. Despite my logged hours - I've played this game with family on a sibling's account for well over 100 hours! So I speak from the heart and some experience ;)
P.P.P.S. Thanks for the updates & new lovely biomes!

I'm very grateful for Dorf Romantik! The visual style of puzzle is very appealing. I don't do so well with classic 'puzzle games' & this game allows me to experience that satisfaction in a way I can actually wrap my mind around. 

Also, it being such a visually focused game, I appreciate how beautiful the developers created the graphics. Staring at something akin to hideous to progress through a game I can find rather grating. In Dorf, I find myself sometimes sitting back and watching the train puff by in the lovely landscape I've just obliviously laid out. 

I also like that with Dorf, I don't have to set aside at least 1 hour to make any appreciable progress. It's really freeing to be able to simply hop in, knowing I'll only play for 15 minutes and it's still a rewarding experience. 

The quests, short term and especially challenge based, are a ingenious way to keep a repetitious game play brand new. With the particular focus of the 3 challenges per game, it can really change the viewpoint of that play-through, allowing you to discover different creative strategies you'd never used before! 

I've really enjoyed watching the development of the game. I've never been part of an 'early access' before, but this one certainly has been rewarding. The updates always add enhancements to the game and I feel like I just received a brand new bundle for free! (Especially the creation of a whole new bunch of tiles - that was an exciting update!) 

The music is also great. It's a very soothing background, with enough variety to not drive you crazy (especially if you are playing for hours at a time :D) I've done sound effects work professionally and theirs add a very nice touch of creating a gentle, easy-going environment. I was very impressed. 

Lastly, and mostly, I really like Dorf Romantik because it's such a genuine game. It doesn't have to compete and be cutting edge, mature themed, excessively mature themed, or horrifying. It treats people as people - and not an enhanced human of superiorly attuned reflexes with skills of a veteran soldier or an ex-zombie, thief, assassin, or prostitute. It's just a really simple game, that's peaceful with an attractive environment, that people can relax & enjoy being in (with a little bit of challenge) as we all struggle to navigate through our own day-to-day. I really appreciate what the devs at Dorf Romantik are doing in providing such a game and I wish there were more like this. I'm very, very grateful to them. Thanks so much!

Dorfromantik is a very aesthetically pleasing, peaceful game of tile placement. You get to build a landscape from hexagonal tiles - creating pine forests, patchwork fields, meandering rivers, spidery train tracks, and higgledy-piggledy little red-brick towns. 

No competition, no population, no politics, no win, no lose. Relax, take it easy. 

There‚Äôs just something wonderfully meditative about clearing your mind and focusing on building out little villages in quiet forests while the relaxing music plays softly in the background.

This is a prime example that early access games can truly be something special and even though it has someways to go for it to be perfect it will always draw me in with it's fun game play. Truly a great game for SIT BACK AND RELAX. RELAX. RELAX. Let your mind wander. You are in a forest. You look around, but you have never been in this forest. The trees are trying to tell you something: MOOOOOOOOAAAAANNN... MOOOOOOAAANNN... You start to back away from the moaning trees when you feel the ground start to give. You stumble a little but catch yourself before you fall. You turn around to see a pit: at least a mile across, going down into the earth until you can see nothing in the blackness. You cannot breathe. Behind you, you hear a flurry of leaves and then you are struck in the back by a swinging tree branch. You tumble down down down down down down down down down into the abyss. Time passes while you fall, then more time. You lose track of the time that goes by. Is it months? Years? You ponder your life. Did you SIT BACK AND RELAX enough? Did you waste too much of it caring for others? Who was that clown at your eighth birthday party who you caught kissing your mom in the garage? Why does everything suddenly feel greasy?

How am I supposed to place that when I have my river on the right side of the map and all my railroads on the left? I end up having to build my railroad and river network toward the middle. Ugh!

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
This might be my favourite game of all 2021/2022. Never have I seen such a nice Early Access phase. Now with full release it is my favourite puzzle game to just play, relaxe and forgett about everything else.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You place hexagonal pieces on a playing field. The adjacent sides should be identical (field to field, forest to forest, etc.). New pieces are unlocked by perfect placements (all six sides placed correctly) and completion of quests (create X amount of fields, trees, etc.). The game ends when the part table is used up.

[h1]Artstyle / Music[/h1]
It looks simple, but everything fits together perfectly. On special parts, which are unlocked through quests, three-dimensional animals (deer, foxes, swans, ...) also move around.
The music is very realxing and chill.

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
It probably sounds crazy, but despite my 100+ hours in Early Access, I hardly experienced any bugs. I have never lost game saves or the like.

[h1]On a special Note[/h1]
The developers do a really awesome job supporting the game. There is a community Discord Server for general conversation, questions and also reporting bugs.

As the game invades my dreams after having spent more of my waking hours playing it than not, I come to the realization that if I were to explain this game to someone, I would be forced to say, "The only thing that matters is staying alive forever." Moreover, the way you "stay alive" in this game is by being a perfectionist.

I am glad I have come to terms with my own mortality, lest such a thought send me spiraling into soul-crushing depression. The game mechanics force an odd perspective on things. I won't assume that luck is absolutely required, but the fact that I will not "achieve" things without buying time is a sour reminder that my years-long work in real life may not be completed.

Definitely recommend this game, although there's still room for improvement.

PROs:
+ Really beautiful graphics
+ Quite simple concepts, yet difficult to master
+ Controls work well (rotate the tile or the map, zoom in/out, pan the map)
CONs:
- Random piece generator is... well... random (sometimes you can't find the missing tile)
- Adjacencies are sometimes less easy to spot
- Bonuses are sometimes less easy to understand, especially for new players
- Game options are REALLY limited. Why don't you allow custom games where I chose the starting number of tiles and the "mission" bonuses - even if these custom games do not count towards the global leaderboards?
- Wish for a few additional game mechanics (e.g. mountain regions or roads)
- Wish for some more action on the map - as of now it's a bit too static, which is sad

Would love to see some additional content and game modes, it definitely holds some additional potential!
Overall, a LOVELY game, even for the full price, I think it's worth it! 9/10.

A nice little tile laying game with some good puzzle elements. The gameplay is simply laying down tiles to create a countryside. As you do that though you'll get tasks to do like building a forest, farm, town, etc. of a certain size. These are easy at first, but get bigger and bigger as the game progresses. These can get challenging later on as say, the forest your expanding begins to encroach on the village you're also trying to expand. 

All in all a nice, fun little solitaire game.

[h1] Puzzles and Art [/h1]
This game's Sound design and aesthetic really add verity to the hexagonal puzzle side matching game loop, and the seemingly adaptive visual design takes this verity to the next level turning this game from a puzzle game into an art generator that uses puzzles as a measure of quality. I recommend this game if you have free time and money.

Dorfromantik scratched a somewhere between 'Carcassonne' and 'The Islanders' itch for me. Simple and addictive to sprawl out your tiles out, but challenging to perfect and optimise your placements as you weigh the satisfaction of aesthetics vs. high score.
I've been onboard since early access, having never been disappointed in the additional content provided to the game. Any potential wants I had were addressed and added over these various updates (creative mode, solutions button, timed, monthly etc.). Glad to see they were able to expand to the Switch - as this is truly a wonderfully enjoyable experience with endless potential for tile puzzlers.
The monthly leaderboard mode is a great addition in conjunction with the Sakura biome!

I don't often review games, but when I do, it's generally because I love it. Granted, I only have 20-something hours on this game, but I absolutely adore it. It reminds me of different board games I played growing up, but is chilled, relaxed and really pretty to boot. I own & play on the Switch as well, and it's an ideal game to pick up and play for ten minutes or a few hours at a time. I love the different biome styles, I love how the tiles blend together, I love the challenge of making a massive forest or rail line or whatever - but especially love just how relaxed it is. A genuinely excellent game I can't recommend highly enough.

Dorfromantik is a strategy puzzle game which sees you placing hex tiles onto a board to build a beautiful landscape. Progression is made by connecting the right tiles together (forests on forests, train tracks next to train tracks), with added bonuses if connecting the right number set in a task.

It aims to be simple and pleasurable, and wins on both accounts.

Great price too. Highly recommended.

This game feels like a single player Carcassonne with missions. There are currently two modes: High score and creative. In high score mode, you earn tiles by completing missions (link over 30 houses together, create a forest with over 200 trees, close off a set of fields, etc). Your score depends on the placement of these tiles (10 points for each edge matched, for instance. There is no time limit so you can take it easy, placing the tiles until you eventually run out giving a score at the end. As you progress you also unlock more tile types to add variation the better you get.

Creative mode has unlimited tiles and you can change which ones are most likely to appear next. 

Both modes are relaxing, unless you get obsessed about beating your high score :D

Dorfromantik is a perfect casual game for those who need something simple to stimulate your brain when you watch stuff on your other monitors. That's the best elevator pitch I could give the game, it's a simple puzzle game of matching tiles for resource adjacency points. The longer you can keep going without running out of tiles, the more you'll unlock and farther you can look back on your progress.

I recently nominated it for this year's Steam Award for Best Game on the Go because this game can be started up and picked up anywhere and be played immediately for a few minutes or several hours. It's absolutely worth full price, a steal when you can find it on sale.

Dorfromantik is a nice casual puzzle game that is definitely worth giving a shot! The name means a romantic village/small town in German.

You basically get a new tile to place everytime and you have a fixed amount of tiles, which can be increased by completing some quests. This is the puzzle element in the game to make as big villages you can make without running out of tiles. You can actually make some really beautiful looking towns and countrysides! I really really like the art style and the multiple themes they have for every tile. One run im making a frozen winter-ish town and next game there is lush fields in pleasant spring. It's a very calming experience and something great that you want to play in between doing some other tasks or just stress relief. Whenever i play it i feel like im in some countryside just sitting on a ledge near a farm and watching the sunset, those feels.... And also it was developed by a small indie team from Berlin, so grats guys! Spiel ist sehr Gut! :)

This game is incredibly fun and addictive. It is both simplistic in design leaving you with just a flow of building this peaceful and nice world, but adds a touch of complexity if you want to try and perfectly place tiles down and build up a high score.

The core gameplay is just placing hexagon tiles down which represent different terrain types. Matching up similar types will give you better score. You can also expand out and unlock new tiles. As a world builder for D&D I got this game to help give me inspiration on land design, but now find myself playing the game when I just want to relax and unwind.

**Steam Deck**

Thanks to this games controller support, this game plays perfectly on the Steam Deck and I have yet to run into any issues with it.

This game is everything it claims to be and at the same time much more than what the trailer or description make you expect. Plainly, you cannot actually realise how challenging it can be unless you are playing. It is the perfect combination of beautiful, relaxing and interesting. The achievements are designed perfectly to aid you in getting the trickier parts of the game and help it remain interesting even if you have unlocked all tiles. Quests make you reevaluate the whole strategy you ve used to build your map so far. You get caught between your want to create something aesthetically perfect, and the need to keep completing tasks to have the tiles to do so.

All in all, 10/10 already and cant wait to see what it will look like coming out of early access.  And though the price tag might seem a bit high to some, it is well worth it if you re into this kind of game, and comes with the added pleasant feeling of supporting a very small but very talented team!!

TIP: shouldnt need to be clarified but if you re like me it does- PLAY THE TUTORIAL!!! Though the main concept is pretty straightforward and might make you feel you dont need it, it will help you get the finer points of the game AND a pretty little reward. I spent too much time wondering what to do with those little flags....

- the music is relaxing at first, but since game sessions can be very long, it quickly becomes repetative and annoying. Better to mute it and put your favorite chill ambient tracks on background.
- the fields align with each other terribly even if you try to match them perfectly. A large area of fields look like an ugly cracked orange surface. This really breaks the beauty of forests and towns
- I wish it was possible to intersect rail tracks with rivers with automatic bridge building

But overall it is a tranquill experience that delivers on what it advertises.

Overall: 
This was an early access game review previously but even after after released, I am still happy with this! Similar to Islanders, Dorfromantik is a fun and cheapo casual game with no specific end game except to keep placing/getting tiles or to challenge the scoreboard. A set of tiles will be given at first and you gotta do quests/tasks (and closing them) for more else the game ends once you are out. Would buy again but only during sales as there is nothing much to return for (at least for now).

Pros:
+The graphic is very simple yet detailed especially after you placed enough tiles to be surprised by what you have done. It is very enjoyable as the little boat/train go around your city/island.
+Surprisingly fun and addictive gameplay, you will wish for more tiles as you reach the end. Thankfully, you get the option to continue on creative mode (free build with no points counted). 
+I often spent couple of hours on a run for achievements without even realising it =X
+Early access game but build is quality and game is bug/crash-free so far (fingers crossed lol).

Cons:
-You won't just wish for tiles; you will wish they tell you to close borders of quests/tasks for the extra tiles. You will also wish that you can undo mistakes or drop crap tiles (looking at the damned combination of train and river tile). Very frustrating when you only need 1 or 2 more tiles to complete the awesome build. 
*Note: You can continue on creative mode but getting the points/achievements do float my boat thus don't mind me, thank you.
-Again, similar to Islanders, game is straight forward and you just place tiles given to complete quests/tasks. Other than that, nothing else for me except to chill and enjoy the view. Will go a few more rounds for higher scores (e.g. 30k) but after that, probably will not return till I need this itch scratched again =(

Dorfromantik is a tile-based, placement planning, city builder puzzle game with challenges and unlocks - an intriguing mix between Concrete Jungle, Islanders, and Triple Town.  The basic concept is simple, and once you get it the challenge is to get your score as high as possible - thus the better you get, the longer your play session. The visuals and background music is very relaxing, almost like a virtual holiday. I can definitely see someone playing this while doing something else e.g. listening to a podcast. With the game's complete release, regional pricing and a nice discount, it's an easy recommend from me (edited for the Steam Awards badge).

Relaxed solo puzzler that seems to draw some inspiration from tabletop game Carcasonne.
Basically you lay tiles to form or connect fields, cities, rivers and even train tracks.
The game will give you challenges, such as making a 12-tile long railroad or a town counting 67 houses.

Completing a challenge will give you a few extra tiles to place, but when you eventually run out the game is over.

Dorfromantik has some other challenges integrated into it's system, that will let you unlock new tiles or buildings for more variety. Some places tiles have add life or movement to the board, such as a train driving back and forth, a deer in the forest or a boat on the river. These little diorama's can be chill to watch, as the game does not include a time limit.

Dorfromantik is a simple puzzle game, but it's in that simplicity where its beauty resides. You can try and achieve all the goals and play optimally, or you can just relax and play as you want, placing the pieces as you find them the most aesthetically pleasing. The soundtrack also places you in a relaxing mood. It‚Äôs truly a wonderful game to wind down after a stressful day!
Nice relaxing game that gets my little ocd devils running laps around my brain to get ONLY PERFECT TILES

Very relaxing, soothing game ‚Äî but a real time-eater!

The game's simple enough ‚Äî you get a random tile (which is any combination of grass, woods, water, train tracks, fields and houses) which you then place on the game board. How you place it matters, as it scores points (and points mean prizes in the form of extras tiles, etc), and you get the most points by joining and linking areas of the same type. You also get missions to complete (e.g. 10 linked tiles of water) that net you even more points, or even a special tile.

Easy.

Except it isn't, because the challenge is how to deal with unfavourable tile draws without the game board spiralling out of control into unchecked sprawl of useless tile placements... Thing is, drawing a card you can't use is slightly mitigated by the fact you get a slight preview of what's coming, but still, if you're trying to close out a fields mission and all you're drawing are trees, water and houses... sigh...

Strangely, this game manages to avoid being stressful, despite RNG unfairness, mostly due to the zen peacefulness of the tile placement, which at core is a soothing, repetitious act, and this is the game's real niche ‚Äî it excels as a winding-down, de-stressing activity... But be careful when playing ‚Äî a "quick half hour session" can easily become an hour or more, simply because you become enrapt in the tile placement, creating your beautiful landscapes...

This game is definitely worth your time (if you like this sort of thing), and as a further inducement there's a sandbox mode where you can create "perfect" worlds (you still get random tiles, but you can skip ones you don't want, and clone ones you do)

This is the most relaxing game I've ever played.

This is not really a city builder, a strategy game, or a simulation, despite Steam's tags. What it is is a very chill game of placing tiles. Although you can run out of tiles in any given session, you never really lose, as each time you play you unlock even more tiles allowing for even more combinations of tile edges. 

And sometimes you simply won't care if a session ends; not every game needs to be about winning, or even beating your high score; Dorf Romantik is the perfect example of a game where the actual gameplay act, choosing where to put your tiles, can be just so relaxing that that's enough for you. It's certainly enough for me. This game is so good for just whittling away at your pent up work-stress.

The way I understand it,
Dorf Romantik was originally started as a university project intended to help students learn advanced game design concepts.

With that in mind,
It is my opinion that the success and continued development of Dorf Romantik have created a unique experience that has evolved into something very special!
Toukana Interactive has created one of the most relaxing puzzle/strategy based city building games I have ever played.

I have personally played Dorf Romantik for many hours, and would highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for a new perspective on a relaxing city building experience.

Dorfromantik is a charming little low-stress world building puzzle. This is the perfect kind of game that you can sit down and relax with on a Sunday morning while enjoying your cup of coffee.

The core of the game consists of placing hexagonal tiles to form the world mostly as you see fit. The catch? You have a limited number of tiles to place, but you can get more by completing challenges that pop up such as connecting tiles with x number of structures, clearing flags that pop up by placing tiles such that the structures have no more connections, or simply by filling in gaps with tiles that match the surroundings very well.

Overall, the graphics are charming, the music and ambient noises are calming, and the experience as a whole is enjoyable and relaxing. Highly recommend checking this one out.

This is a super chill game that I'd describe a bit like "Carcassone single player that you should play while drinking some tea". You can place pieces anywhere, but the idea is to have as many edges line up as possible so you get more points. There are some various "quests" to do certain things, but you can honestly just build whatever you feel like and you're not really penalized. You're REWARDED for making good plays, but it feels more like bonus than the "optimal" gameplay, if that makes sense. 

It's very zen and I really enjoy it and probably should play more.

Nice chill game. Like a hex-based carcassone.

One thing to note: if you are obsessed with getting all the achievements, this game will not let you scratch that itch. As far as I can tell, for each game you start you get assigned three random achievement categories, and no matter how awesome you do in that particular game, you can only unlock achievements in those categories (other than some broad ones like total points, etc).

For example, I know that I've built a village larger than 50 houses loads of times, and that I've built forests larger than 750 trees most games I've played, but since those two achievement categories were not active in those games, I have not yet earned those achievements.

The achievements bit is annoying to me, but considering how insanely difficult the top tier of achievements is in this game, I doubt I would ever 100% this game.

Update: It does seem like they are addressing player feedback well.

The fastest way to explain Dorfromantik would probably be "Carcassone Solitaire" and, while reductive, it certainly gets the point across. In a slower way: Dorfromantik is a single-player tile placing game where the objective is literally score attack but, in a broader sense, is about perfect tile placement. A game of Dorfromantik, like Carcassone, ends when the number of tiles remaining is zero but. unlike Carcassone, you can replenish your tiles by completing - and I use the word rather loosely here- challenges. This tile says it wants to be connected to 37 tiles of wheat/field, so you better connect EXACTLY AND NO MORE THAN 37 tiles of wheat/field but this railroad says ay buddy how you doing can I get uh at least 50 railroad tracks and you go sure I got a the train equivalent of a Jormungandr over here lemme just slap you in there.

And that gives you 5 more tiles.

I mentioned perfect tile placement. When you surround all six sides of a tile with a perfect match, which you'll know when its perfect because that side will glow white as opposed to red, you get bonus points as well as another tile back. So, playing well enough can, theoretically, make the game never end.

If you like Carcassone, you'll like this. If you like light single player puzzle games, you'll like this.

Built on a similar idea to the classic, popular tabletop game 'Carcassonne', this is an incredibly cool, and occasionally frustrating, game that I would probably call a 'map building game', cause I can't think of a better quasi-genre. Some people call it a chill game, I kinda disagree, as I at least tend to get tense and even a little anxious when my tile-stack gets low and my game is nearing its end!

You can earn various neat aesthetics for this in-game: things like river tiles with a beaver dam, forest tiles with wildlife, and you can also earn alternate biomes that change the overall look - most recently a Sakura theme, which is *gorgeous*. I wish I could nominate this game for more than one catagory in the Steam Awards!

A nice and relaxing gaming of what's best described as a landscaping. In the default mode, you get a limited number of a hexagonal tiles and need to place next to an already placed tile, in an ever expaning map. For completing "quest" (like building a certain size forest) you get the extra tiles and points. Game (and player's estethics :) ) promote placing tiles that match each other's side (i.e. house, forest, field) - especially if all sides of a tile are matched, you again gain new tiles and extra score. Games ends when you run out of titles to place. However, they are also other modes - challenges, equivalent of creative mode etc.

Very relaxing game, simply place tiles to build charming villages, trains with pointless routes (this is not a city management sim!), huge tracts of farmland, and rivers/lakes for little boats to wander.  Scoring is based on connecting like-edged tiles together or completing quest tiles.  Quests are generally simple, such as "connect this House tile to 4 more House tiles".  There's no timer, and the only competition is yourself.  Scoring points will gradually unlock variant items that will show up on future tiles.  Haven't noticed any bugs or glitches, and the only minor stress I've had from it was trying to complete some later-game quests before running out of tiles.

I really HATE to give this game a Down Vote because it truly is quite a neat game.

The only reason I'm giving this a Down Vote is because of two things...

1. Four Excruciatingly painful Achievements to shoot for namely:

*Planner V
*Planner VI
*Puzzler V1
*Puzzler VII

2. RNG

These four Achievements, actually a lot of the Achievements for this game will require you to rely on a good Tile Roll because I've come really, really close to getting at least Puzzler VI with only five (tiles) remaining to complete the Achievement which is to plop down 200 consecutive tiles that do not have any incompatible edges, so that eant I've already plopped down 195 of said tiles with only thirty tiles on my stack remaining. "You still have Thirty tiles to use, so what's the problem then that's plenty enough", you might say. The problem is, this game's RNG loves to piss you off. In those thirty remaining tiles it'll most likely hand you four or less of what you actually need and the rest will be tiles that'll screw you over.

So yeah, fun and pretty chill game actually, until you try and shoot for the game's Achievements and the game's RNG decides to screw you over and be a huge pain.

Its relaxed objective-based mode drives gameplay without being overbearing, and its achievements and unlocks reward the player for smart moves as they progress. By adding the small animations to tiles, it emphasizes the feeling of 'building' something, and helps bring the player into its serene realm. Sometimes you want to lay down tiles instead of looking for 50 different resources to build your town while barbarians hassle you. This is an excellent game for a daily chill down with a cup of tea. Not to say it's necessarily easy; success depends upon paying attention and planning for the future. It's also beautiful. 

The game strongly resembles some of the European board games that have made this a golden age for board games. Not coincidentally it is being made into an analog version too.

Recommended for a good solo board game.

The main advantage with Dorfromantik as opposed to other digital board games is its solitaire mind frame.  no AI to worry about, just get the highest score possible.

Dorfromantik is a puzzle game: You are given a stack of 50 tiles (where each side can be forest, farmland, empty, buildings, water, or traintracks). Some tiles give you quests (i.e. link up 50 buildings to this hex) which give you 5 tiles when completed. Some quests also drop a flag when completed, which gives you 5 more tiles if you block off that quest type (i.e closing the forest region off). You also can get 1 tile if you place a hex perfectly (i.e. each side is touching another hexside with the same stuff in it).The goal of each game is to play until you run out of tiles. The game has objectives, some of which are always counting, some of which only count if it is one of the three objectives given at the start of each game. If you complete those objectives you unlock unique tiles (i.e. a windmill hex where all 6 sides are farmland). Each objective has multiple levels which grow in difficulty/time investment to complete. This is why the main gamemode is a puzzle game, not a city builder, you are trying to last as long as possible and get as many unlocks as you can in one run. There is a creative gamemode which gives you unlimited tiles and the ability to skip or delete tiles you don't want, but to get the unique tiles in the creative mode you must first unlock them in the base game. Overall, it is a very fun game, and can be pretty relaxing (so long as you aren't trying to complete one of the harder objectives, such as placing 200 tiles in a row without having any tile side touch a hex whose side is different).

I got frustrated with the stealthing in Metro exodus. I got frustrated with the Realm of Tzeentch in Warhammer 3: Total War. I fired this up. It delivered what it promised, which is a stare-at-the-nice-landscape quiet contentment, combined with elements of light puzzle solving. Would play again.

I'd like to add that it's the perfect game to play as you're listening to an interesting podcast. It keeps just enough of your brain on what is being said.

City "Builder" and "Simulation" are IMO completely misplaced labels as there is no resource or production management or a any tech tree, which I all consider necessary elements of those genres. (I do not count the tile supply upkeep as resource management).

I should have watched the video trailer to know that this game is not my cup of tea.

Relaxing. Satisfying. Gorgeous aesthetic. Lovely background music. No levels, no rush, no objectives other than 'place X tiles of Y sort' to gain extra tiles. It's a slowly growing landscape of your own making, with cute little villages, train tracks, lakes and rivers, forests with deer, and even the changing of biomes with regional differences/seasons of sorts.

Looking for a laid-back puzzle game with a relaxing atmosphere that let's you play as you wish - with optional challenges and difficulties - then this game is more than worth its price. Buy it, play it, relax and enjoy!

Dorfromantik is a puzzle game where you create an idyllic landscape using hex-tiles.

At the start of the game you are given a a number of tiles. The aim of the game is to match the corresponding sides of randomised tiles to score points and complete objectives. Completing these objectives awards you more tiles. For example, you may get a city tile that requires +50 houses. If you connect enough tiles and sides to have that number of houses, then you complete the 'quest'. This also applies to trees, rivers, train tracks and fields. 

My placing more and more tiles you end up creating a randomised landscape that's different each time. The game's simple graphics and gentle soundtrack, accompanied by the occasional moo from a cow or choo from a passing train, make the game a joy to watch unfurl. There is also a creative mode if you don't want to bother chasing points. I would put this game in the same category as Townscaper or Islands, it's very simple  but you can lose yourself for hours. 

A relaxing puzzle/city builder, Dorfromantik is well worth your time. Make a cup of tea and enjoy!

If you are feeling burnt out or overwhelmed this game can remedy that. It helped me a lot during college and those random nights of exhaustion but its more than something to relax too. There is a surprising amount of depth when choosing where to place your tiles. 

Should I try to make a perfect space and get max points? 
Should I complete this objective in order to get extra tiles? 
Should I fill out that plot of land simply because it's annoying to look at and I want this run to look pretty :3 ? 

All these questions will be put on your mind but not in a manner that induces stress or anxiety. And that's what makes it so great. It can be deep when you want it to be and it can relaxing when you want it to be.

The Music is also fantastic and perfect for what the game is trying to accomplish. This is a great game and I would recommend to pull the trigger if you have your eye on it.

I had a little trouble choosing my rating on this, as I would say my feelings are very mixed on it. Initially, I really enjoyed the game and thought it was a relaxing low-stress but fun experience. However, over enough time (2-3 "cities") I found myself getting bored. I suspect this is how the game it designed and it's a reasonably priced game so I am generally positive on it, but please be aware: 
1) The game never meaningfully changes. All mechanics are presented as-is early on, and the only changes I found were cosmetic (new looks for tiles). If you aren't having fun early, you won't later.
2) It can be frustrating because the tiles you get are random and sometimes really hard to place intelligently

With those being said, the game is extremely accessible, and relaxing. Some of the results can be really nice  looking and it's fun creating pretty landscapes.

The best summary I can think of is: Do you like Carcassonne and would want to play a 1 player version of it?

I'm giving this game a negative review because I believe it is overhyped and even ‚Ç¨12 is a steep price for what it is. 

Yes it looks nice, yes the soundtrack is very good but after an hour or two you start to realise that that's it. The gameplay is in this weird limbo where you can't really make coherent landscapes because you are supposed to cluster certain tiles together to rack up points while certain tiles prevent others from being placed. It's a fairly boring puzzle game and it's definitely not a city builder. You always end up with a, granted, nice looking but wholly uninteresting patchwork of random tiles that you need to throw away to make a new patchwork of random tiles. The only form of long term motivation beyond 2h of gameplay is unlocking new tiles that don't do anything different than the other tiles and for some reason there is a highscore system that completely goes against the zen nature of the game but I guess you gotta make everything competitive these days...?

One of those games that is very definition of "easy to learn, hard to master."  It seems simple enough... matching tiles with different landscape types to make a pretty vista.  But there's some deeper gameplay here, and while you can just have a fun time slamming down tiles, you'll hit a wall until you unlearn some bad habits and assumptions.  Bigger isn't always better, and attempting to make every goal are two issues of mine that often led to me running out tiles early and prevented me from getting bigger scores.

I think if I had one main issue, it's that the need to connect the outlying quest tiles to unlock new goals and eventually tile types wasn't made very clear.  I kept wondering why I had clearly made a forest of 500+ trees on several occasions but didn't get the achievement until I re-read some stuff about the game.  I may have missed something somewhere in the tutorial, but it would be nice if this was made a bit more clear up front.

As a person who likes indie puzzle stuff, this ain't it.
As a person who doesn't pay attention to cost much, if I did, then this REALLY ain't it.

Very little content, very little reward from matching tiles correctly. Quests just make you play the way you'd already play, by keeping similar types together. When you complete a big one, there's little feeling of reward. Nothing really unlocks in later play, nothing to build towards (far off quest tiles do not feel like a reward)... the terrain just sprawls out so much that keeping tabs on which tiles you're looking for to complete a hole gets tiresome.

And as other people said, the "hours played" is inflated from time the game was sitting while I watched a video or walked away.

This game isn't 'horrible'. At first I felt an urge to build out the tile map. But after a couple quick games (including tutorial) I was already near my limit. I started a new game with the intent to focus on quests so my game time would last longer. Unfortunately, every game I played i got worse and worse tiles, including a significant number of related tiles in a row without any quests. When you got like 20 water tiles to place, the game suddenly begins to seem loaded. 

After my 3 or so games, I felt like there is no purpose to the game, it is very monotonous and boring, and I felt more aggrivated with my tile choices and irritated that planning seems to be intentionally sabatoged by the game. your chances of getting a tile that is good for a particular spot needing >3 sides is very slim, even if you had a number of them just prior to needing one for a particular spot. 

I cannot see why anyone says this game is relaxing, i found it the opposite of relaxing, boring, pointless, and am done with it within a couple hours or so.... and played the last game already in this state from the prior games. Dont waste your money. I know the game looks interesting from the game page, but it definately is NOT overwhelmingly positive to play.

Dorfromantik is a perfect game for relaxation. 
Sure, you can figure out exactly how the game works, all the little details and try to get the highest score possible, but that, to me, is not the real strength of the game. 
The thing it does best is to challenge your mind just enough to keep you invested in the game, while also keeping it real simple. 
All you do is rotate tiles and fit them into ideal places to either satisfy your sense of asthetics or to earn higher points by combining alot of forest tiles for example (or housetiles, watertiles and so on). 
Combine that with relaxing music and overall great rural sounddesign and you have this game, which doesn't do a lot, but what it sets out to do it does very well.

Tetris if it were a city builder.

Although I use the term "city builder," I feel like it needs clarification when describing this game.

The main attraction of city builders is the satisfaction one gets when creating something complex and/or beautiful. In most city builders, these creations are premeditated in that they stem from an idea of something you'd like to make. In Dorfromantik, your creations are almost entirely a byproduct of your pursuit for survival and high scores (unless you prefer Creative Mode). 

After finishing a long session in Dorfromantik, it's satisfying to look back at all you've done. Although you don't plan for the end result to look the way it does, there is a sort of natural beauty in the score/survival driven creation. There is a history to each board.

That being said, I think you'll be disappointed if you're not into high scores and your main motivation for buying this game is its city building and creation aspects. I like how the city building aspects manifest in this game, but I don't think they are all that engaging when separated from the scoring/survival aspects.

One more thing. It's easy to fall into a trance-like state while playing this game. That makes this game perfect for those moments when you want to engage your mind with little effort. If you've ever played a lot of Tetris, you know what I mean.

In short:
If you like Tetris & city builders, buy this game.
If you like Tetris & not city builders, buy this game anyway.
If you don't like Tetris, find God.

Dorf Romantik is a tile placement puzzle game where the player will create a rural landscape.

The player is given a supply of hex shaped tiles featuring houses, trees, rivers, lakes, wheat fields and train tracks, and you‚Äôll decide where to place them, ideally matching together tiles of the same type. Some rare tiles have tiny trains, boats, or animals, which will move around the map when placed.

In the classic game mode you have a limited number of tiles, but can earn more by completing quests which ask you to connect a number of the same tiles together, or by making perfect placements where all edges match. Your objective is to earn the highest score possible before you run out of tiles. 

Each run should take around 1-2 hours, but unfortunately the simple gameplay mechanics felt a bit repetitive after only a few runs. I also don‚Äôt like that the tile generation is completely randomised. I always seem to end up with some blank voids in my map that I can‚Äôt fill in because I just never get a tile that fits properly.

There‚Äôs also a creative game mode where you have unlimited tiles to expand endlessly without worrying about quests and high scores, although you‚Äôre still limited by the random generator and you can‚Äôt earn achievements.

Despite my criticisms, I think its fair to say this is a good game that just doesn‚Äôt suit my own personal preferences.

If you like Carcasonne for the village-building you'll be into this. It's an incredibly relaxing board/puzzle game with pleasant music and simple objectives. Connect enough like tiles and you'll rack up points and turns, though I'll admit I screw myself over finding the exact right fit for farms and forests so everything looks "pretty". Be warned, this can be super-addictive. Getting that perfect tile to place just where I need it gives me a real dopamine rush, and it's hard to break that cycle (especially if you have ADHD) since you'll inevitably have created another several spots waiting for more perfect tiles. I've had to uninstall this game a few times so I can get things done or sleep! Lastly, if you're a completionist you'll still be challenged, as it's quite difficult to unlock new tiles. You really have to go into the game dedicated to unlocking it, and even then you might come up short. All in all, this is highly-recommended but proceed with caution if you're one to hyper-focus.

[b]Dorfromantik[/b] scratches that itch for a game I can pick up super easily to kill some time, but is still interesting enough that I can get hooked and end up playing for an hour or more.

It's a very relaxing game, and the gorgeous soundtrack is a perfect complement - I just wish it was on Spotify so I could carry on listening to it after I'm done playing :D

The core of Dorfromantik is to place a series of hexagonal tiles next to each other on a large grid. Connect the same types of tiles together for a few bonus points, place a tile that matches on all 6 sides and you'll score a 'perfect' and get a bonus tile. Sometimes you get 'quest' tiles which need to be connected to a large, connected string of a certain type of tile in order to get a big bonus pile of tiles.

This all seems simple in its premise, but once you get into it you realise there's much more strategy than first meets the eye. Firstly, you're always running out of tiles with every tile you place. If you reach 0 tiles, the game ends. You can make a profit on tiles by completing quests, but what if you get a quest that needs a large forest and you've not got any forests large enough? Or any forests with open edges to carry on adding to? Some quests also need a specific number of items - e.g. be connected to exactly 36 houses - if you only have one megacity in the middle of the map that you add all house tiles to, you'll fail that mission instantly.

Strategising and keeping your map in a certain way to prepare for as many missions as possible is the heart of the game, but it's not as tedious as it might sound. Paired with the beautiful soundtrack, calming visuals and cute atmosphere effects (birds, animals etc. roaming around on the tiles), you watch your map slowly come to life as you try to survive as long as possible without running out of tiles.

In short; Dorfromantik is a relaxing and easily-replayable 'pick up' puzzle game. It's easy to play but also easy to lose, so once you've learnt the basics you can begin strategising to get the high scores needed to unlock more and more of the overall meta quests.

Very nice and well crafted strategy game. It's extremely basic and easy to understand, but allows for depth through the multitude of choices the game gives you every single turn. Every tile is a important and impacts the future of the map you're on. The differing quest variants force you to think ahead and make often times, decisive decisions. Overall, really fun, relaxing, and simple while not sacrificing player agency or how skilled a player can get.

Cozy, fun and addicting. I love puzzles and this just adds a nice beautify and purpose to one

Honestly, I'm not sure I will play this very often, because the zen focus causes me to lose all track of time and far too much sleep. It's an experience very much like the last time I worked on a large jigsaw puzzle until I realized blearily it was 3am. My 15 hours was only 2 games, split into maybe 4 play sessions, as I can't help but search for the best place for every tile once I'm more than a hundred tiles in. If you have a hyper-focus problem like me, then consider yourself warned...

There's a fair bit of hidden depth to the gameplay beyond tile edge matching. You learn to pay attention to quests (which reward more tiles to your stack to continue playing if you, say, grow a forest enough or close off a set of fields), assess their relative attainability, and choose between incompatible options. And, after a couple of games, it's also become obvious that really getting to know the tile set's ins and outs would help - it's broad but not complete, so when you place that 3rd or 4th tile adjacent to an open hex, you might be creating a hole that is easy to fill or guaranteed to cost you points later. Some tiles with more than 2 types of terrain only have one handedness (clockwise or counter), for instance, and rivers and tracks in particular have pretty limited patterns of terrain on their other edges. Whether I actually want to spend the time to take notes (or study someone else's notes on the web) just to get better at this dangerous time suck of a game, I don't know yet :)
Finally, we can have..peace.
An excellent 2nd monitor game if the movie playing on your 1st monitor is kinda slow.

Dorfromantik is a great game. Very relaxing and easy to lose yourself in, it's hard to describe other than as a zen, "city builder" puzzle game. You just place randomized tiles on a board, optimizing for points if you're going for scores--or appearance if you want to lean more into the sandbox and worldbuilding aspects. As useless as "this game is like X" comparisons often are, I'd put this somewhere around Mini Metro/Motorways; but instead of a minimalist aesthetic mimicking subway lines or road maps respectively, Dorfromantik goes for a very cozy art style that's easy on the eyes and really drives home the relaxing vibe the whole game has. The ambient audio and gentle music also contribute strongly to that feeling.

Really, I've got nothing to complain about, major or minor. It's a wonderful game that's an absolute time sink--there's been sessions where a single game has gone on for well over an hour and I haven't even felt the time pass. It's definitely worth picking up if you're looking for something to relax and zone out with, and is an easy (strongly) Recommended from me.
i love this game. its simple but lovely. so worth it.

Tranquil, relaxing, and addicting to the core.

If I had to describe it in one sentence, I‚Äôd say [i]Dorfromantik[/i] is essentially therapy bottled up and sold in a video game format. It‚Äôs fun and cozy, and I‚Äôd recommend it to anyone who‚Äôs a fan of city builders. Heck, I‚Äôd recommend it to Joe Blow down the street.

This is a low-stress game that I find myself thinking about even during periods when I‚Äôm not actively playing it (a testament to how unforgettable it is, which I wasn‚Äôt expecting), and a game I often itch to return to when I‚Äôm stressed out. If you‚Äôre looking for something pleasantly simple to escape to after a long day (or a long life), then this is the perfect candidate.

My only qualm is that it does get rather repetitive and somewhat boring after a few hours. The good thing is that it‚Äôs really easy to pick the game back up, even if you haven‚Äôt touched it in a few months.

All in all, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs absolutely worth buying ‚Äî the concept is great, and the quality is exceptional.

TLDR: I place tiles down and happy chemicals in brain go brrr.

Fantastic, chill puzzle game, ridiculously cute, one of those games that are very simple in their setup but offer a ton of fun along the way! Cute things to unlock over time, neat strategies to discover, and absolutely amazing for playing while you're watching your favorite D&D show (Dimension 20) or listening to a podcast or something.

Be warned, however: the urge to place "just one more tile" is very strong!
A super relaxing game and it's so satisfying to keep expanding the landscape. The sessions aren't very long so you could spend less than an hour a day playing.

Want to spend 20 minutes to 20 hours just quietly and calmly putting together a sprawling landscape complete with rivers and villages and a smattering of lakes?
This is it. 

If you don't care about points, you can play forever at a time without a lot of thinking, but the game can be challenging if you strive to make everything match up perfectly whenever possible. 

The soft music is pleasant but turns off easy if you prefer an audiobook.
Each game is different so your score will jump high and not so high!! ;-)  Fun game with no pressure to move fast.

Dorfromantik is one of those games that is very simple to pick up and relaxing to play. The challenges are really those which you put upon yourself - largest map, most creative design, meeting in-game achievements and quests or just trying to beat your last high score. 

At its core its a basic 'board game'/'card game' style game. The graphics and sound are more than adequate for this style of game and are just as relaxing to look at as the game is to play ! 

While I dont think I will spend as much time playing this game as I do say, Crusader Kings or Rimworld, this is an easy to pickup game that will give me something to do between games or when I just need to chill.

There's not enough here for me. And I get that simplicity is at the core of this game but it just needs a little more to it imo. One idea, for example, would be special tiles which you can accumulate as quest rewards or whatever and they are available at any time to play. These would obviously be rare but could fill a specific need on demand. I'm looking for a little more control over what I'm able to do. I also think there should be some economy type bonuses such as connecting a large urban area with a large field area or connecting two urban areas. This would simulate trade and tourism.
I played for a few hours and it was alright but there's zero urge to play any further so I can't recommend.

Super chill and casual game,  highly recommended. Great game to play after a long day at work. Good also to play in the background while looking after kids, as you can leave and come back to it any time. Thank you devs!

after a long day of questionable life decisions, I like to sit down and unwind by placing pretty pretty tiles in a hexagonal pattern, and plot how I will one day destroy this land I'm creating in a socialist revolution.

During the first couple of hours it seems relaxing, looks and sounds nicely. Later it feels too random for a set of tiles this large (each particular tile, if you need one, has too little chance to appear). It's also visually difficult for me to understand if trees or houses occupy particular side of a tile, because it looks "too natural". Constantly rotating it on the actual map is tiresome.

In the end, it becomes simply more frustrating than relaxing, and I wouldn't say that resulting landscapes look that good. Waters and forests are nice, railroads and cities are OK, but those yellow/purple fields are unbelievably ugly.

I wish that this game would have less complex tile mechanics, or even more challenging rules, or at least would be more beatiful. For me it's neither, so here's my downvote.
So peaceful, yet so engaging! Love this game. Frustrating? Sure, but that's my brain's fault, not the game.

This game is absolutely phenomenal. It's so simple yet complex. I have an extremely stressful job and this is my go to for relaxing after an overstimulating day.

I have been playing since day one and as relaxing as it is to play this game I just want more.
After 40 hours played I just wish the Devs would add something new. I feel even with the different modes its still just the same thing. Some sort of progression or new tile types, themes, little people populating the world I build. Groundhog day comes to mind. 
I do really love this game but for now I just think it needs to be fleshed out more. 
Hopefully someday it will blossom.

I have played this game for 91 hours as of this review, and personally I have enjoyed it a lot. The game rewards patient and thinking, instead of spamming tiles. There is diversity in the two different categories of tiles, being water/train and house/tree/farm. The water train station is also a great piece. The game itself isn't bad, it just hasn't reached it fullest potential yet. 

What i mean by this is that there are plenty of additions the devs can make to the game. As of now there has not been a lot of updates. The big update with Quick Mode, Hard Mode, Creative Mode etc. was a great update adding a lot of new content. But that was mostly gamemodes and not features. I have some ideas I hope the devs will atleast take note of. 

1. Timelapse
A great way to showcase what you have accomplished after a you lose.

2. Different skins
Although I adore the style of this game, something they could add is different houses, different trains, etc. to make the world more customizable.

3. Hills
As I said before, the style of this game fits the premise, but it feels a bit flat. Whilst it doesnt need to be complicated, some hills would help out the feel of the world. The hills would also make for great for more diverse landscape, like if you were to have a water tile next to it, it would have a cliffside etc. 

4. More diversity
Although the houses work just fine. There are only a handful of different types of houses you get, the tower, watermill, windmill, and the other structure usually next to fields. What I would love to have is different buildings, for example a lighthouse if a full water-tile has one house on a side, or a trainstation where it would usually end, a lumberjacks house if a house is next to a large forest, a fishermans hut next to a little lake etc. This goes for boats and trains too, maybe have a slightly bigger boat, or a longer train. I truly think this would make the feel of this game even better. 

5. Scarecrow
Idk, the fields are kinda empty. just add some scarecrows

6. Boat and train view
I saw someone make a post on reddit of a mod they made where you could see the game from a boat or trains perspective. Personally i think this would be a fun way to take in what you have accomplished, kind of like the timelapse mode. 

I don't actually know if any devs are going to see this, but I truly hope so. I have loved playing the game ever since I got it, and will continue to play. But if any devs are reading this, please think about my suggestions.

So it's a calm game where you build a delightful pastoral countryside. But it's also a puzzle and a surprisingly satisfying one at that. There's the satisfaction of placing your tiles just right to get points and reach milestones, but it's also just a chill game about creating a beautiful world

Dorfromantik is a gorgeous and relaxing tile-placing game where you place tiles to build a map filled with plains, farmlands, forests, towns, rivers and railways. The music lulls you into a sense of timelessness, where nothing else really matters but placing the next tile. Do you want to complete challenges for extra points? Or create ‚Äòperfect‚Äô placements where all the edges match? Or just ignore all of that and go into creative mode to make /your/ perfect map?

Just looking at the waterfall of positive reviews on Steam is enough to encourage a try at this game. I personally found it well worth the investment of time and money, and still go back to it frequently. It‚Äôs not something I will play for hours every day, but that‚Äôs a good thing in my view - it scratches an itch that I didn‚Äôt realise was there, it lifts my mood, it sparks my creativity. At the same time, it lets me go and play other games and do other things, then come back and not suffer the annoying learning curve over and over. Once you know what you‚Äôre doing, then you know what you‚Äôre doing and can come and go as you please.

Admittedly, this  isn‚Äôt a game for everyone. I love it, my partner loves it, many people on Steam apparently love it. But this is not a city-builder, and I hesitate to call it a strategy game. As another Steam review commented, it‚Äôs more like hexagonal dominoes with a different skin. I find it incredibly relaxing and especially when I‚Äôm sick, this is a great game to just turn my brain off and focus on the pretties. When trying to get achievements or fulfill quests however, it can get annoying trying to make do with the random tiles you‚Äôre given. For some people, the annoyance can overrule the relaxation.

From a purely mechanical gameplay perspective, Dorfromantik is incredibly well made. I have yet to encounter any bugs, and Toukana Interactive are addressing those bugs which others have found. I have only played the PC version, not Switch, but I can see it being a really good portable game as it‚Äôs something you can pick up and put down as needed without worrying about losing out on anything. 

Toukana Interactive have yet to release other games onto Steam, but I for one am eagerly waiting for them to announce their next project.


Top 5 Pros
	- So relaxing
	- So pretty
	- Different challenge modes, or creative mode which lets you just build
	- Chill soundtrack to go along with it
	- Sensible pricing


Top 5 Cons
	- The randomness does mean that for some people it‚Äôs more frustrating than relaxing
	- See above for repetitiveness
	- Showing only one tile at a time does increase that frustration and lowers the ability to strategise
	- Having achievements locked behind quests gets very irritating
	- The quests themselves can get in the way of having a relaxing time

Would I recommend?
	I recommend reading a few reviews and deciding whether it‚Äôs the right game for you. It‚Äôs not for everyone. For those who it does fit, though, it‚Äôs a lovely game well worth the price. If you‚Äôre not sure, buy it on sale and give it a try.

(More reviews at www.quirkyandcute.com.au)
You can make it fast paced or longer and strategic just based on your liking with no specific game mode. You have numerous ways to figure out a strategy to stay alive longer to build more
This tile layer is reminiscent of Carcassonne. It's light, easy to learn, and relaxing.

This game has pleasant visuals, a chill vibe and is surprisingly addicting. It's not super complex and is easy to play, especially when doing something else at the same time. I would put it in the same category of games like solitaire or candy crush, something to play while on a hold on a phone call or while watching TV.
yes

I requested a refund. There's simply no depth to the game. It's peaceful and relaxing but you see all the game has to offer within an hour. I wish there was more to it because the art direction and concept are very well done. It's just too shallow for me. I loved my first playthrough. After my second playthrough I lost interest.

You can definitely spent a lot of time learning how to master placing your tiles. If you are more of a patient and contemplative type of gamer, who likes to really perfect your approach to something, you will get your money's worth out of this one. If you like being presented with new challenges or having some variety to your experience, skip it.

This is a very chill game, yet with enough of a 'puzzle' element to keep it from being mindless. It does get a tad frustrating when you get to a point where it doesn't seem like there's anything you can do to succeed, but then you also have the option to continue in a creative mode. Worth replaying to collect more tile variations.

This is a piece of software designed to pack your soul in cotton.

Dorfromantik is a meditative strategy game with a calm soundtrack and pleasant art style. This game helps me relax whenever I'm feeling anxious. There's lots of creative options with the tile placements. You get to create your own little world, complete with towns, rivers, farms, and etc., and the world is unique every round. The game offers you objectives to increase your current score. Following these objectives are optional for those who aim to obtain a high score. There's also a creative mode if you just want to place tiles endlessly. Overall, Dorfromantik is a wonderful landscaping game. It brings serenity and fun. I'm happy I stumbled upon it and I definitely recommend it to others.

Wow. Amazing is the only word that comes to mind. I love strategy games, and this is certainly  new twist to that genre. No bad guys, enemy bases or complex civilizations. On the surface it looks like a simple puzzle game, but there is a lot of deep gameplay here and earns the title of strategy game in my opinion. 

I foresee a lot of hours being spent on this in the near future!

The ultimate chill out game! I'll often sit down and start a round, then an hour goes by in the blink of an eye. There's a decent amount of strategy to this game, but you can definitely throw strategy out the window and just build a cool map.
